Posted: October 13, 2014
												Do NOT buy this game if you plan to play single player.  It's miserable.That said, I absolutely recommend this game for co-op with 3 or 4 players.  This game is a very tough gauntlet-style game, with puzzley elements frequently thrown in.  Yes, you are smacking monsters and trying to stay alive, while doing puzzles at the same time.  It's freaking hard.But, it is very satisfying to complete the levels.  The only downside is that the netcode still isn't rock solid.  For whatever reason, I have a 20%ish game freeze rate when trying to start a group game, requiring me to totally shut down the game and restart.  Other than that, it seems ok.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												Don't try this without friends, you'll go mad in singleplayer. Extremely difficult, we've spent over an hour on certain trials (still not done with all of them), especially difficult if you want to do the challenges. Controls work great on a controller, gameplay is overall interesting. The orb idea is a neat one, makes for fun and interesting puzzles, although you might kill your friends over it at certain times. You WILL have to go back and revisit previous levels to do the challenges, which provide the upgrade gems for abilities. I personally like this, challenges are usually fun and they really need teamwork, but I imagine it may bother some people playing the same levels over and over.Plays best if you have friends over, you really need to communicate (yell, actually). The main reason why you really need friends for this. Everyone should have a mic and lots of patience, really difficult to have this with strangers.Got a 4 pack in sale a while back, money well spent. We're at roughly 23 hours so far and still has a lot to offer, so I'm pretty sure you would be happy with it even at full price.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Forced is absolutely brutal, requiring constant team communication, clever problem solving and the mastery of combat skills. It can be an incredible amount of fun and is highly recommended for any group of gamer friends.This game pleasantly surprised me: simple in concept, but with an incredible amount of depth to it.I can’t stress enough how much fun Forced is when you’ve got even just one other player. It’s a smartly designed cooperative action game with a great variety in its challenges, and a great combat system that encourages teamwork over all else.Forced is an honest cooperative RPG with some good ideas suitable for 3 or 4 players but a hard nut to crack for lone wolves.Playing solo is oftentimes more frustrating than fun.However if you’re itching for a hardcore co-op action experience, then you’ve struck gold with Forced.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Forced is a co-op tactical arena game. It can be compared to games like Diablo, but it's not another Diablo clone - there's no loot in this game and its more co-op than any Diablo-like games I played.In this game you play as slave gladiator who is forced to fight to amuse god-like creatures. Thus this game is based around Trials - rather small arena-like challenges. They can vary from "kill everyone" kind of thing to puzzles, mazes and boss battles.You have 4 classes(or to be more precise - 4 weapons) - Volcanic Hammer(AoE melee damage), Frost Shield(Tank), Spirit Blades(Single target melee damage), Storm Bow(Ranged damage) (Each of them have skills to heal each other). In each trial you can get a maximum of 3 crystals (1 for the completion of the trial, 1 for challenge(these will vary from trial to trial) and 1 for time attack). These crystals will unlock new skills(you have a total of 8 active and 8 passive skills for each weapon with only 6 slots(3 for active and 3 for passive)). Also note that your progress is shared among all weapons, so you will get all skills for all weapons simultaneously,Another thing is Spirit Mentor(named Balfus) who is one of the key features of the game. Balfus is your way of interacting with environment and is vital to every trial. To spice things up, you can't just order him to go somewhere. Instead, you can only call him on your current position, which makes everything a bit harder.And about the difficulty - this game is hard. Like, really hard. Not once have I found myself stuck and not once did I go back to gather some more crystals.As a closing note - this game is heavily co-op oriented and I don't know how good it plays in single player. So it will be better if you have some friends to play with.As a downside of this game I can say about quite unstable net code, but devs are constantly working on it.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												I really owe this game a review.  I've had more fun with this playing with friends than any other game.  No other game has permitted me to talk at such loud levels to the people sitting next to me.  It's a lot like gauntlent but a greater challenge in my opinion.  Where as gauntlent is more geared toward grinding mobs down, this is more for how well can you work together on a particular goal.  I haven't encountered many games that make you have to be this tightly coordinated.  Weak links will become apparent and quick.  Each level brings a new way of having to making a plan.  Each monster has to be learned how to be dealt with.  Kiting isn't an option.  Understanding how each fighter operates is vital.  My warnings:  This is meant for co-op.  You can play single player, but you aren't going to have as much fun.  More importantly, you will want to find a consistant person or so to play with, which I know isn't always easy.  Pugging this game usually ends in a bad result, and there aren't enough people in the lobby to make games happen when you have time to play.  Also, I would not say this is for a casual gamer.  If you haven't built up a reasonable degree of twitch, I feel you are just going to get frustrated.  I'm not saying people can't learn, but I've seen people that don't play a lot of games say this is not for them.  Games are fun, but to me this one was an experience.  One I could share with some good friends.

number of helpful: 130 of 158 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
FORCED is a Action Role-Playing Game heavily pushing a co-op experience. STORYI would say the weakest part of the game, other than some of the technical issues that some people still experience (see technical) - would be the story. It's a very quick and short tale that leaves a lot to the imagination. I'm not saying it's bad; simply shallow. If  your goal is to find a rich story - you will not find it here.ELEMENTSAll players have the option to play one of four classes which are determined in the entrance room to each trial room. It is also good to note that no matter the decision of the class; in most cases you will have healing spells, damage spells, and defensive spells of some kind. Other than the inherit differences between melee and ranged; the developers have done a good job at keeping most everything balanced. The true co-op experience comes into play before anyone even enters a trial; deciding who will have which spell to counter the trial mechanics. This is an element that most co-op games don't have.GAMEPLAYOnce your skills and class has been chosen - per challenge - you will face 25 trials with increasing difficulty. As one may expect the game starts out in a tutorial manner, teaching players how to navigate the trial and use new mechanics. Balfus (your spirit guide) is an integral part of the gameplay, requiring players to move him to destroy shrines or statues, light the path, assist in damage dealing, or in some trials - used against you!The primary game play is to complete objectives which range from killing monsters, finding the end of a maze, or simply lighting shrines. As a side note I wouldn't say this is necessarily a game with heavy puzzle elements; however there is a degree of puzzle solving.DIFFICULTYIf you plan on being a completionist, to get all 75 crystals and all achievements, expect to spend some time on this game. At the time of this writing I have completed all achievements in roughly 24 hours of gameplay. Most challenges took my team 1-10 tries; the challenge on the last boss took us roughly 4 hours. If you plan on simply completing the trials to have the experience to play - expect at best half of that. I would not recommend this game if you want to just play single player - this is a game best experienced with friends. Disclaimer: Your mileage my vary, every gamer and team is different you could see significantly less or more gameplay.TECHNICALI have to peck at the game a bit on this level; there are still a few issues with networking that the developers are actively working on. In addition the game is poorly optimized in terms of graphics use. A lot of the options to effectively reduce load on a computers GPU is non-existant. My system with a GTX570 runs this game fine, but quite hot in comparison to other games with a much higher expectation (100% load in some areas running 70c+). I assume as the game matures further, the developers will continue solving some of the technical issues that some players are reporting as problems; they did not effect my team as much as some but it is important to note that they could come up.CONCLUSIONHighly recommended for any CO-OP experience. This game is quite fun with a lot of potential for growth in the future. 9/10 for what it is, and for my experience.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												IMPORTANT NOTICE: This is not really an RPG game in most of its sense; there is no actual character sheet, and when your character evolves, whatever choice you make in that regard can be undone freely. Changing your build is literally like changing clothes. There is no looting or potions. There is no choice of gear other than the 4 basic sets, which are also your "class", and once again, you can freely swap. This is nothing like Diablo (in this sense) unlike other reviewers insist to claim. Bear that in mind.Devilishly challenging yet fair, this here is a masterpiece.You are simply FORCED to undergo challenges in a twisted sort of arena. Endlessly spawning monsters chasing you while you try to solve a maze, or while you run away from a deadly red myst, or perhaps while you try to take cover from a laser beams (lol what?! its magic!)... figuring out how to solve each area is one thing, solving it is ANOTHER THING!Completion of each area is required to access its respective boss, and each completion awards you with one crystal - literally one "experience point" - that unlock skills. Optionally you can solve an area while doing a special challenge (depends on the area) or while time-attacking, each of which award you another crystal. Whereas you might think "Nah, I'm not an achievement hunter, I just wanna finish the game" you might be FORCED (unexpected pun) to change your mind there as sometimes the higher level skills give you a crucial advantage when fighting the boss.There is no difficulty tweak, you cannot switch to "easy mode". Definitely not for people who get frustrated easily.

number of helpful: 127 of 171 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
A bit about the game and developers.FORCED has been developed and published by a small group of Danish developers, called BetaDwarf Studio. They actually had a pretty funny story while making this game. In fact, it was so funny that they even made a picture about it which you can see here.So, FORCED is a Co-Op adventure game with a lot of puzzle elements. The game does future single player, but I do not recommend that.. More about that in the Gameplay section of the review! They also plan to bring this game to Wii-U!About Gameplay.As I said above, Forced is a game that allows both single player and co-op. At begining I was playing this game single player. My steam friend list has a couple of people who own this game, but nobody played at the time when I did. So anyway, In single player the game is quite fun! The story is very good too. It wasn't so hard, and I really enjoyed it. But then, couple of missions later... It became quite hard! So, I got into the game once at the same time as my friend FaithNoMore did. We decided to try the game out in Co-op..It was amazing! The game became much easier but it kept being harder and harder as we progressed through the challenges. In most of the cases one of us was always the last-man-standing, running around the enemies, doing his best to stay alive long enough for the other person to revive. We also found out that this game is actually meant to be played in four people! After a while, our obstacles became quite hard. So hard that one of us had to keep sacrificing just so we could complete a mission. If there were four of us, it would be piece of cake!The game has four different classes, a rogue, archer, tank and a "area of damage" damage dealer. Each of them has their own element. Rogue uses poison and has teleportation skills and skills that get him out of combat quite fast. He's the best class to take creatures down one by one. Archer uses lightning element with which he deals nice damage to couple of creatures at the same time. His arrows also always push enemies back, so he doesn't have too big problem with staying alive. Tank uses ice element to make ice crystal around him which then pushes enemies back, and so on and on. Needless to say he's got the biggest hp. He also has a weapon (shield) which can be thrown away to enemies. Now, the AoE damage dealer uses fire element to deal very big damage to multiple creatures at the same time. Sounds overpowered, right? Well, he does deal big damage, but he swings very slowly. He can also crush a meteorite down onto the enemies.This game also has a lot of different creatures that you have to fight against to win. All of them have their own strength and weaknesses. Some spit on you from far, some charge you with their massive cleaves. And once again, you need a full group of four to make a great tactic on how to win against the creatures.Graphic and AudioGraphically speaking the game looks very good! The game itself looks a bit cartoonish. The skill effects look quite nice. For an Indie company they really put their backs into it! Voice acting in the game is very good too!Pros, cons and final grade.Pros:- Very cheap!- Extremely fun!- Supports four players at the same time!- Full of puzzles!- It's an extremely fun, cheap coop puzzle based indie game!Cons:- Almost unplayable in single player.Final grade: 9/10 !Extra info: If you're into puzzles and you're searching for something to play with your friends, this game is for you! Don't look anywhere further, just buy this game and play it. It's amazing!Thank you for reading my reviews! Don't forget that I'm usually posting new reviews on my blog weekly and you can check them out here:[/b] http://midnightwolfie.blogspot.comThank you![/b]

												If you are looking for a couch coop game, this one is the best or one of the best.Levels include increasingly challenging puzzle and hack n slash level. Some levels are almost purely slow puzzly levels, some are fast paced fighting levels and rest are some combination of those two.Game mechanics are simple and are introduced sufficiently smoothly so you don't feel overwhelmed. Later on these mechanics are combined in various ways and the game never feels boring.Biggest con for this game would be that its not a single-player game. You can play it alone but its not even half the fun.So if you are looking for a coop game to have fun with your friends this game is for you.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												FORCED is an insanely fun co-op puzzle brawler. You play as a slave being trained up to be a gladiator and you are exposed to 25 challenging levels (5 bosses, 20 challenge rooms). After 30 hours of playing the game (it can definitely be completed MUCH faster), here's what I think..Pros:- The game is infinitely more fun with co-op partners. The difficulty fluctuates a lot depending on whether you do a challenge solo or with a group. For example, some challenge rooms are easier to do with more people. On the other hand, some boss rooms require a lot more concentration with a full group due to the higher amount of adds. Either way it is a game that does a great job of promoting teamwork seeing as the 4 available weapon-types have a specific role to fulfill.- The skill variety is ample enough. There are 3 passive and active slots and there are enough skills for all types of situations.- There is a large variety of different challenges rooms with various objectives. There are 4 acts (or areas) and all of the puzzles are different. No 2 puzzles repeat so you can be sure that the game stays 'fresh' until the end.- You get to face challenging bosses. Each boss has a speed challenge and a 'self-imposed' handicap challenge. With these 2 challenges, you can't just face-smash your way to full-on victory. Fully completing a boss level requires a certain level of precision and understanding of the room's mechanisms.- The spirit guide's dialogue is quite well-done. It was entertaining enough to get me through the entire game without getting complacent.Cons:- The Camera feels very limited.- There is currently a glitch that sinks the 3rd player in any group under the floor when entering or re-entering the preparation room. They are currently looking into it.- High latency can cause issues in some puzzles. These issues can block progression.All in all I loved FORCED. I haven't had that much fun in co-op since playing Magicka. I would like to see more puzzles in the future. The bosses were alright but the puzzles felt a lot more satisfying/rewarding when completed.9/10 and looking forward to sequels and other releases from this developer!

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Edit #1: This game is pretty hard.  When I play this, I get quite frustrated, but I like a good challenge.Some of the challenges seem impossible, but it might just be because I'm a newb.In this game, each "level" is referred to as a trial.Each trial has 3 achievements you can unlock:-Completing the Level-A unique level challenge (such as beating a level without killing monster spawn points, etc.)-And beating the level with a speed run aspect to it (Time Trials).When you beat a trial, you earn "crystals" which are basically level ups for your gladiator.Crystals unlock active and passive skills to make your hero stronger.There are 4 Heroes (weapons), you can choose from, and that you can change at any point in the game:-Volcanic Hammer (Warrior class)-Spirit Claws (Rogue class)-Ice Shield (Paladin class)-Storm Bow (Hunter class)It plays like an arcade game, but man, it is pretty hard, and my frustration is a 9/10 most of the time. lolThe cool thing with this game, is that the puzzles and monster spawns scale with the number of players in a game.So the more players, the harder the game is!For completionists, the good thing is that you can compare your rankings with other players from around the globe to see how well (or poorly) you've done.All in all, a good game, and would recommend even at full price. :)[END OF EDIT]~~~~~~~~~~So far so good!I've been eyeing this game for quite some time now, and have passed up various Steam sales, either out of forgetfulness or laziness.66% Off, 50% Off, I finally picked this game up for $2.24 (85% Off), and the initial game play is decent so far.Initially, the game has a Gauntlet Legends/Warcraft 3: Custom Map/Use Map Settings vibe to it.The game plays similar to StarCraft 2 Challenges, mixed with some Gauntlet Legends-Arcade style vibe to it.I've read the reviews prior to mine where the difficulty ramps up as the game progresses, and isn't fair towards the later stages of the game... (Dungeon Defenders suffers from that, where you HAVE to play with people)I haven't gotten that far yet, however, when I get to that point, I'll be able to update this review and give my whole-hearted opinion of the game.There is one thing though: the story/voice acting, albeit, is minimal thus far, is very lacking/dry. (Supposedly the game was created with a team of 7, so it's just a side thought.  You aren't playing the game for voice acting, you're playing it for the fun factor!)All in all, the Trials are challenging... it gets me frustrated trying to race the clock and I get killed in the process. lol.I promise to update this review as I progress in the game. :)

number of helpful: 31 of 40 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												The game is quite different from what I expected when I was buying it. It's not that much about puzzles or real combat skills (I imagined something like dodging at the right time, using different attacks per enemy weaknesses, combo-ing, etc). No, it's more about great cooperation between players (voice chat is an absolute must), selecting correct skills from the skill tree for that particular level, and, unfortunately, also about grinding. The game is quite hard, don't expect a casual multiplayer co-op game. You'll need to repeat every level many times to at least finish it. And then, you'll need to repeat it many times more in order to fulfill the challenge or time criteria. If you don't do it, you'll be very much underpowered in the later levels and the difficulty will go from high to insane.So, the principle of the game is not to enjoy many different levels. The number or levels is quite low (25). The principle of the game is to rinse and repeat until you finish them perfectly. It's not what I expected and it's not what I enjoy, but tastes differ, I'm sure many people will like it. That's not why I'm giving it a thumbs down.The thumbs down goes for technical execution. From technical level, this game is horrible. Network issues are extremely common - the game splits and people see different things on their screens, someone can't move at all, someone dies but gets stuck in the dying animation and glitches the level, unable to complete it, and the list goes on. But, that's not the worst thing. The worst thing is the camera. It deserves a paragraph on its own.The camera. The devs had an idea that you need to see all characters at the same time, all the time. So if you go into different directions, the camera zooms out to make sure you see all characters. Questionably a good idea, with the worst implementation ever. First, this camera mode is mandatory, you can't switch between "focused camera" (seeing just yourself in the center of the screen) and "overview camera" (seeing everyone). No, it's just the overview camera. So, if you go far apart (necessary in some levels), you're zoomed out immensely, and your characters (and enemies) are very small. Try to use your skills effectively then! You're also in a corner or near the edge of the screen, so you have no idea what's near you in certain directions. The camera constantly shifts (as others move around), which throws your aim out of balance (especially frustration when playing the archer character). And to top all of that, the devs even botched it so much, that very often the camera actually crops your character and you're behind the edge or the corner of the screen! So, you don't actually see yourself, or the enemies around you, and you're expected to fight them and survive. Please don't forget this game is extremely punishing for even the smallest errors. You'll cry, you'll shout, you'll tear things apart. That's how bad the camera is.One final note, this game has to be played with a stable group of friends. No one might be missing any time. The reason is that every time you start a game, you'll only receive those gems, which have been completed by *all* members of the party. So if one of your friends was not available last time, you'll need to repeat all levels with him/her again, and complete all of it again. This was not the best design choice, and again, you have no option to configure this, you need to live with it. Consider it, if you don't have a stable group of friends to play and finish this game with.So, to sum it up, the game mechanics are not necessarily bad, they can be even enjoyable. But the technical execution is definitely a reason to avoid this game. And that's 18 months after release, so there's no hope of having it improved, ever.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Lots of fun. Great game for the casuals AND the hardcore gamers. It's a challenge even if you don't look to complete all the achievement ( I did...I got hooked...It's awesome ^^ ). You never stop improving and if you're up to the challenge, you're going to have loads of fun. The adventure is great, with a steady learning curve. You get to learn how to play each of these four badasses if you feel like it or you can just go and solo one of them if you have a favourite, it's not impossible to finish the game if you do.Bosses are sometimes a bit easy because the strats are quite simple to understand BUT most of them are still challenging because in this game, knowing what to do is the easy part, being able to do it is a whole other story.If you have a trustworthy group of friends though, buy the fourpack, and solve these levels together. The more the merrier. Really. Especially since some of these levels take you by surprise : there's nothing funnier than seeing your friends panic and getting slaughtered in every side of the map because of some new content to the game ^^ (Beware of the fog !).Finally, the new mode they added, survival mode, is a gem. The first levels are a bit easy to beat imo, compared to the rest of the game, but the last one is....evil. I can't imagine playing with 4 players in this last level, but I'm guessing it must be the funniest experience this game has to offer. You'll understand once you get there ^^Also, there is a 'last man standing' level in these survival maps which seems pretty interesting and very promising in a way that I'll surely spend nights with my friends playing this level only and having fun helping/betraying your friends to survive the longest time possible =D.Overall an incredible game for those who like puzzles, badass characters with skill trees and passive trees, and last but not least, a little bit of challenge, for a price that is, in my opinion way underappreciated.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Cooperative Action Puzzle RPG. You collect crystals throughout levels by beating them, and optionally, completing challenges. These crystals unlock active abilities, passive abilities, and slots for both active and passive abilities (up to 3 each). There are 4 varying classes you can choose from any time while in the hub. You can't have more than 1 class chosen at a time. My favorite class is Frozen Captain America.It's got simple combat where you can dodge most enemy attacks with good timing, and puzzles involving an ethereal sphere dude you call to your position, that you can also carry with you. It's used by guiding it through shrines, which can have a healing, explosive, speed boost, etc, effect. You can also guide it to a block, which can be pushed and pulled to your location by calling it. You can also activate other things, like torches, as well as purify things and destroy enemy spawners.The game has about 20+ something stages, and a challenging boss and new environments after every several stages.It's a pretty difficult game, and I suggest you try it with at least one other person, or you'll probably go mad in solo.

												Incredible game. Hits the right balance between "these developers are evil!" and "holy crap I just pulled that off!". The four classes are well varied and the skill trees are very interesting. Toying with characters builds is quite fun. The story is simple but the early twist plus good characters and good voice actors make it engaging. Coop (and local coop!) makes this a great party game too. Posted: December 25, 2013
												Word of Warning. This game is very heavy on Time Trials and alot of replays on missions. I don't see how a single player can do it with out spending alot of time redoing the missions or watch a youtube video on tme. We play about 10 missions and we completed in 5 mins or less per mission. Some of the time trials wanted you to complete the mission in a min or less. I purchase this for my brother and me and with two players using TeamSpeaker we had a hard time and it was not enjoyable. Game play was more like,move the orb around, light this stuff with the orb, blow this up with the orb, kill this device with the orb, then a hack and slash game with puzzles. We forgot all about the mobs and was just trying to get the mission done in time. I feel like the mobs of bad guys was just an annoyance and didn't help the game play. When you goal is trying to solve a puzzle in time, to get the crystals, to get new powers. I would not recommend this game, unless you like replaying the same lvl over and over and over to get the pattern down on using the orb at the right time to get all the crystals.  Also the game "About the Game" is so short, i believe because they was afraid if they gave you too much info you would not play the game. I will do alot more research on a game before buying in the future.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												An interesting game with great co-op mechanics, the game ultimately lost my interest and patience with an unforgiving and unmitigated difficulty curve.  There are no difficulty settings and the "RPG" elements don't really afford you much benefit, at lease in the sense that in most RPGs you can grind/build up in reponse to a challenge you can't yet overcome.FORCED gives you no such luxury or mercy.As a result, unless you consider yourself a hardcore gamer, you'll likely find yourself frustrated with the game mechanics in subsequent acts past the first one.  There is no end-around or alternative strategy that will ease the challenge for the sake of completing the game.  Instead, there are brick walls.  You must find a way to climb them.  The game will offer you no quarter, even with friends.Ultimately a shame, because the co-op build and design is really enjoyable.The diffuclty level, for me at least, was a very unfortunate and very disappointing dealbreaker.

number of helpful: 16 of 24 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												For detailed impressions of FORCED as of 23/12/2013 check out: http://tap-repeatedly.com/2013/12/impressions-forced/"We were all pleasantly surprised and impressed with FORCED. We came in expecting a game along the lines of Torchlight but got something entirely different, refreshingly unique and sharply focused. I think it’s one of the best co-op games I’ve played over the last few years and I really can’t fault it for putting teamwork, experimentation and thoughtful proactive play at the front of the experience. We all initially sort of scoffed at Balfus (the orb) as a bit of a gimmick, but he’s arguably the star of the show, binding players together and really underlining the importance of cooperation. When you throw all the varied trials, challenges and puzzles in there as well as the enemies, the different shrines to activate, the slick and satisfying combat, the character classes and the skill pools to dive into and play around with, you’ve got a game that’s unlike anything else out there.BetaDwarf describe FORCED as ‘tactical arena co-op’ or ‘co-operative gladiator action’; whatever it is, it’s brilliant and absolutely worth your time and money if you’ve got a few budding buddies."

number of helpful: 20 of 30 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I played this game co-op with a friend. I have not tried single player. That said, the game was quite fun with one other person and requires a signifcant amount of teamwork to complete challenges and to fight bosses.FORCED is an interesting take on the action rpg genre. Instead of running around solely fighting hordes of monsters, you have arenas that you must enter and complete challenges. You also have an NPC that you must guide around who is an integral part of completing these challenges, which usually involves calling him to particular locations, causing him to move over shrines or other objectives to complete objectives while monsters are there to get in the way and make things more difficult. I wouldn't go so far as to call these challenges puzzles, as it is usually pretty obvious what needs to be done and is more a matter of execution.There are a panoply of abilities you can unlock to help you destroy monsters. They are unlocked by completing arenas, completing them quickly, and by doing special objectives in them. There are four classes and you are not tied to a particular one. You can change your class any time you are not in an arena and you will have the same tier of abilities unlocked on each character, so you don't have to level each one or anything like that.The boss arenas are fun and each one has their own interesting set of mechanics. A few of the arenas and one of the boss fights in particular (the skeleton, for reference) are quite difficult, but that just makes beating them all the more satisfying.So all in all, a fun game to play co-op. I'm not sure about the single player aspect of the game. Having had a multiplayer play through, I have no interest in going through a second run solo.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Don't buy this game for its online multiplayer.  If you can even manage to connect to someone it's practically guaranteed that everyone will have crippling amounts of lag.  For a co-op oriented game all I can do is shake my head at this flaw.I really wanted to like this game as Gauntlet 64 on the (you guessed it) N64 was one of my favorite games of the time.  Also, Forced IS a fantastic game when it runs properly.  The puzzle component of the game adds some much needed "spice" to the hack-n-slash genre and the arena design is fantastic.  The limited RPG components of the game worked just fine and allowed for some character customization, combined with the solid gameplay it's a recipe for success.In the end, none of the games' strengths matter when you can't even hop into an online co-op match and have fun with your friends (or strangers).Don't even buy this when it's on sale if you want to game online with your friends.  You might as well flush the money down your toilet.  It's made even worse by how obviously solid the gameplay is when you play solo... such a shame!  A lot of TLC clearly went into this one but they messed up one crucial thing.  The devs can go on and on about how they are fixing it but that is total BS.  It should have worked right on release.  Selling a busted P.O.S. like this should be analagous to fraud.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												A terrific game that allows up to 4 people to play. I wouldn't recomend it while playing on your own though since that kinda defeats some of the purpose. Unlike other ARPGs or whatever we call these it's not focused around finding gear and leveling up. Instead each stage has a mission, a purpose. These are simple puzzles or annoying challenges that you need to find a plan on how to solve. It could be lasers, or bombs or just a simple "kill everything mission". After a mission you are returned to a "world map" inbetween missions. You may change between 4 classes and 2 people can't be the same class. The classes act a little different and are good for different things.In each mission you can earn 3 crystals, which is basically the leveling up system of the game. Once you reach a certain number of crystals you unlock additional skills you can use instead of the basic ones. How do you earn the crystals? It's a little different depending on the mission but mostly it's about clearing the mission within a certain time frame, not taking damage or doing something fancy. Great game, but play with some friends.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Best co-op game for hardcore players I have ever played.Grindless hack&slash with puzzle elements for up to 4 players. It is divided into 25 diverse 5-10 minute missions, each with additional challenges (one speedrun and one tied to specific level features). Furthermore, there are 3 co-op survival maps available as well as a competitive "last man standing" survival map.After first missions the game gets progrssively harder (from the 12th level onward you will die regurarly). The game is fair in its difficulty though - every attack can be avoided if played properly.There are 4 classes available, each with its own niche. You can change your class and build anytime. The secret to the victory is finding the right team composition and strategy to beat the obstacles.There is no grind. Progression is based on a number of missions and challenges you managed to finish. "Leveling up" does not change character stats, but unlocks new abilities you can choose from, diversifying your arsenal rather than making you outright stronger. You can take up to 3 active and 3 passive abilities, so respeccing for particular challenges isn't a chore.The game can be played single player. It tunes its difficulty to the number of players quite well (some levels are a little bit harder, some a little bit easier when playing with friends).

content:
Posted: October 23, 2013
												Hypothetical situation you're a gladiator and spirits are always with you because you have a spirit mentor he's called Belfry or something. He has a mental disorder, so he's got multiple personalities and one of them is a capital arsehat. that's why you have to be a gladiator. Once they establish the plot, you get to punch a scarecrow with a weapon and then you get to punch it REALLY hard and then you're a real gladiator. This is a good game to play with a controller. After you're a real gladiator, you have to go fight real enemies, and then you're a true gladiator. Once you do that, you can start playing actual levels, and then you can be acknowledged as a gladiator. Levels are fun with friends, if you happen to have any. Friends are useful because they do everything wrong and will inevitably make the game harder. So don't try to play this with friends, they're usually really bad at this. If you do play with friends out of the kindness of your heart, it is not required that you acknowledge them as gladiators. You may opt to refer to them as peasent, commoner, or perhaps dead.Fighting is fun because you pick a weapon and then you kill enemies with it. When you kill an enemy a few times, it loses health and gains marks instead. Marks are sort of like a currency in this game, where enemies can trade you their health points for more marks. Once they've made this trade, they can opt  to sell them to you in exchange for more damage. Through this method, you can kill enemies, and become a gladiator. Becoming a gladiator is harder than just killing enemies though. you need to get crystals and stuff, and those let you get more abilities and passive things and active abilities and passive abilities, as well as skills which you acquire by collecting gems. There is also a soundtrack in the game, although I do not remember any of it. It is probably gladiator music. I can not confirm this. I would give this game anywhere from 10 to 12 dollars, because I think it was on sale. Now is a good time to buy it, since you can get it at full price again. This is a definite must-have for anyone that thinks they might like to be a gladiator, in any sense of the word.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												Typically single player games have co-op features that aren't requirements to play and pass the game. FORCED on the other hand is a single player game that HAS TO BE played in co-op. The challenges scale so that if there are fewer players you may need to do a task fewer times or kill fewer enemies, but it's still challenges created with co-operative play in mind; you may need to carry a ball fewer times across the screen but you still need to carry it across the screen rather than alternating with a partner. There are four heroes, each specializing in different tasks and the game comes into its own when they're all working together taking advantage of their specialties. You can conceivably play this title single player but it's an experience meant for co-op. Preferably 3 people or more (max of 4).Like any co-op experience FORCED spends little time in cutscenes or dialogue; there are 5 hubworlds you travel to in a small overworld map, each with 5 levels and a boss. Each level gives you a max of three crystals: one for completion, another for completing a challenge specific to that level, and a third for completion under a certain time. It's a relatively short game if you're just aiming to pass levels and face the bosses. Despite that several levels and bosses present a WORTHY challenge and will require some coordination and strategizing on your teams' end. Otherwise length and replay value comes in trying to do the challenges and finishing the levels under the time limit. Many of the challenges further the co-op aspect by requiring some modicum of strategy in finishing them, whether that be lining up the shield hero so that he tanks hits whilst the archer attacks from afar so that no one on the team is hit by a particular enemy, or positioning heroes so that an explosive object doesnt touch enemies on its way to its objective in a timely manner. I don't know how its even possible to complete some of these tasks in single player.The point in completing challenges is for crystals; attaining a certain amount unlocks more abilities for your class and/or slots to use abilities (maximum of three). The abilities are obviously different for each class, and they have their use depending on what you're trying to do. You can use one of your slots for a healing ability to aid your team in bossfights, or you can switch it out for a rapid fire attack to take out many smaller enemies that may present issues whilst the rest of your team is focusing a large enemy down. Pre-levels there's a moderate amount of strategy in synergizing heroes and abilities to get the job done.Good and pretty short co-op experience, but that's the big thing: unless you have a group of people to play this with don't bother. It can be fun playing alone, but it's like playing payday or left4dead alone and without bots. It's made to be a co-op title and without it it isn't as enjoyable.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												A very challenging top-down puzzle action game that heavily focused on coop gameplay. Be aware, you WILL die tons of times.In every stage, you get to choose one of 4 different equipments, each have its unique skill and usefulness. The game mechanics are pretty straight forward. Every few stages it introduce a new puzzle element, and each stage you earn medals to unlock more active or passive skills for your characters.Although this game can be played solo, coop is still the way to play it. I completed the game with my co-op buddy in 2-player coop, and how I wish we can actually get 4 players to enjoy together! The game scales pretty well depends on how many players are in the game (for example, the more players you have, the more enemies will be spawned, and the target objectives will be harder).The graphics and musics are not bad. The plot is negligible. Glitches still occur occasionally, but most are cosmetic. Nothing game breaking. This game handles networking pretty well. If you are playing online coop, as long as the internet is not too terrible, the game is very playable even with a little bit of lag.For Achievement HuntersAll the achievements are doable, but will require you to get good in the game. This is not a very popular game, so game guides are quite scarce. Some of the stage challenges are easier on single player due to reduced difficulty. Most of the stage challenges and time challenges requires careful planning, practise, and a bit of luck.My score: 8/10

												Wow, is this game fun! With the sarcastic and whitty narator/sprite that helps you out, lots of enganging trials to go through and complicated traps to dogde, along with some varying enemies, this game is a must. You can even change your class at any time before a trial, making it easy to switch to what your team needs. I haven't finished yet, so I can't speak to the end storyline, but I do know that the trials ARE difficult and increase in difficulty as you beat bosses. Heck, my group and I died so many times in that poison room then again in the rotating laser room. Yet what the game does well is that it doesn't beat you down if you fail. In fact, we would've all kept at the trial until getting it if one of us didn't have to leave. So yes, I would highly recommend this witty little game. Grab it for yourself and for a few friends, because they'll love it to (or simply tell them to get it. I mean really, do they think you're full of money or something?).

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												The bottom line?  FORCED has some issues, but it's well worth your time to play, especially if you can play with friends.Upon starting FORCED, I faced some serious problems trying to get controllers working. Supposedly these issues have all been fixed now, so hopefully you won't suffer the same hassles.  Even if you do, however, I recommend you perservere and get it set up to play.FORCED is first and foremost a puzzle game. Yes, the combat plays a significant part, and you will get good at the combat (and will need to), but the puzzles and the teamplay is what makes the game.  Trying to work out how to complete levels, and then complete the challenges and time trials is genuinely fun and will make you think and strategise, which is a really refreshing change of pace from so many other games.Perhaps the biggest issues are the occasional bug that can make a level impossible, the aforementioned controller issues, and the skill unlock progression.  Some of the high levels skills unlocked later in the game are *really* underwhelming given the effort you've gone to acquire them, and the last unlock requires you to complete everything in order to obtain. That's right, you have to do everything in the game in order to unlock the last abilities, and even if they weren't hideously disappointing (which they are), that would leave you with nothing to do with that ability.While FORCED enjoyable solo, I would most heartily recommend it as a fantastic game to play local co-op, I've read reports of issues with the net-code for playing with others online, but playing with multiple people on one screen is great.I'd really love to see more from FORCED. I'd love to see more levels, and ideally some reworking of some of the skills available - there are a number that are basically useless.  Still, FORCED is well worth your money and your time.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I'll make this very short - this is an excellent game that is very much worth your time and money. If you have some to play it with, that is - ideally someone sitting with you in the same room.The game consists of a disconnected series of "trials" (aka levels) with an overarching, persistent upgrade system and four classes you can change between at will between runs. After finishing six of the 25 available levels, I can say that thinking up and implementing strategies for achieving each level's extra goals (finishing it within a given time limit, plus one level-specific goal) is really satisfying.You will be running the same levels over and over again, but there's no grind - you will be trying various approaches, or attempt to perfect the execution of a strategy you thought up (it's not the hardest game in the world, nor does it try to be, but it's decently challenging for your average gamer, so that will happen sooner or later).It's not the Greatest ♥♥♥♥ing Thing Ever, but it's a splendid game you might spend tens of hours on and thoroughly enjoy it, and it's an excellent co-op experience. As a fair warning though - one of the game's core mechanics makes it highly troll-prone. Only play with people you know and/or trust to do fine, and as I've said before, ideally with people sitting in the same room.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Disclaimer: Only tried the game in single-player mode so far.And it's great! It kept me up till 5:30 am, and I hadn't had this happen in quite a few years. FORCED is like the child of Diablo and Zelda (the games! not the characters :P). If you like both ARPGs and puzzle / platformers this is for you.You play as a Gladiator, a soul bred and trained for one purpose; to fight and survive the challenges of the Arena. Your spirit mentor, a blue wisp, guides you through these challenges. The game is split up into 4 (from what I can tell) segments, each with 5 trials and a guardian (boss). Each trial (including the guardian) has both a challenge and a time trial as well for extra gems - which you use to unlock skills. It looks like it will keep you busy for at least a dozen hours, if not more.In each Trial, the goal is always very clear, but don't expect "how on earth do I get there?" to also be clear ;) The puzzles pose various tactical (planning) and practical (execution) challenges - some of them very hard. The different classes / abilities aren't just reskins of eachother, they have very distinct effects and there's some synergy within the class itself. The difficulty & learning curve ramp up very smoothly. I also liked that all classes play very well with both keyboard / mouse & controller. Except the archer - he's a ♥♥♥♥♥ to aim with a controller. The only major downside I found was that the combat felt a bit stiff - I had a feeling I was constantly missing a couple more active abilities in my arsenal. Maybe a dodge/block/parry with a really small cooldown?The visual direction this game has is great. You take a random screenshot, it's gonna look beautiful. Very nice color pallette, and it's very functional as well. You never really have "I didn't see that" or "where am I" moments, even amidst chaotic battles. The game's soundtracks are also very well composed and fit each level. SFX are well designed as well, though nothing special. But what really sells the audio of the game is the voice acting. It's actually acting, as opposed to just reading lines. And it's not just your spirit mentor, but the bosses as well, which really helps build up the anticipation of facing them. The game isn't story-heavy (nor does it have to be) but the plot is quite interesting and well written.Overall the gameplay nailed it for me. Great experience and really looking forward to trying local co-op. I'm glad I bought it and would definitely recommend it!

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Lately I became a happy owner of 3 wireless game controllers. Naturally I started collecting (more like "hoarding") locally cooperative games. FORCED is one of the first i bought.It was on sale, and had excellent reviews, so being always on a lookout for some local mp games I thought I'll give it a try. It was an excellent purchase.My buddy and I have sat through it's levels on numerous nights, from dusk till dawn, and couldn't get enough.Surprisingly though game is easy at first but very challenging in longer run. First few levels are kinda slow-paced and trivial, You get to know your characters and their capabilities, and you don't really care for speedrunning, nor challenges, But what's brilliant about this game, is that it makes you go back and revisit levels and play them through perfectly, for sake of progressing through other hard levels.FORCED is a story of skill on a very interesting level. Game such as this- easy to play, hard to master- is not a very common thing these days, so I would recommend it to anyone. Playing with a buddy is greatly rewarding experience, so I'd recommend playing it in coop.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												A unique game that combines both fighting and puzzle-solving skills, with the icing on the cake of the co-op mode in which you can play with up to 3 friends to complete the levels, using both your wits and teamwork.At first i thought it could be another boring "kill and solve this thing to proceed to the next level" game, but damn i'm happy that i were so wrong.The puzzles are infact part that has been very well integrated into the battleground of your levels, it means that you will have to both fight and use a spirit with the shape of a sphere (your main tool to solve these puzzles) in order to beat certain kind of bosses, or just to open a door while running from a swarm of monsters or either avoid lethal environment present in the level, or even activate some for your aid.Even the fighting part itself is pretty nice, 4 different gladiators to choose from, each with their own weapons and unique skills that you will earn as long as you progress into the game by completing the levels themselves and their respective timer to beat, or some "challenges" which will test your skills furthermore.The requirements of this game are also kinda flexible, at the minimum of 2 GB ram i could've run this pretty smoothly, of course decreasing video quality, but with even more recent computers it can run decently at higher settings.One of the best university projects that made into Steam, made with the Unity engine. Definitely a worthy game.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												In FORCED, you are.. FORCED to fight for your life alone or with friends, with up to 4 player co-op with 4 different classes.In this game, you are tying to survive in challenges put on you by gods, made for their own enjoyment. You are helped by this soul to destroy them and free your people once and for all. In ages past, your race is alive only to fight and die for the entertainment of beings much more powerful than you. This will change.The four classes available are very different in what they do, being very solid to the class they represent.The first is ranged, using a bow and agility like abilities and based around lightning. Second, a strength based two handed class using fire and heavy but slow attacks. A rogue is the third, using fast attacks with evasion abilities. The last is a frost themed tank with defensive abilities and stuns to reduce the damage everyone in your party takes. You can choose between them whenever you want, in between levels and depending on what is needed.The game is a mix of a hack and slash with puzzle elements, really focusing on teamwork when played with others. I found the gameplay boring by myself, but when I played with a friend it was much more enjoyable. It can be very difficult at times, requiring a very good amount of game sense to dodge certain abilities and do certain puzzles. The bosses are very well thought out, giving a nice end to each chapter. They are also very unforgiving.The price is pretty high when not on sale, much too high for a game like this (its pretty short, being completed in around 8 hours) and I would recommend only getting it on sale. Make sure you get a friend who kinda knows what a hack and slash is, because its much more fun with another person, but having an inexperienced player makes it much much much more difficult.Overall, 8 hours of gameplay, hack and slash gameplay with puzzle elements and four classes. Don't buy on full price, wait for a sale.Personal Rating: 3/5

content:
Posted: January 27
												TLDR; Kind of tricky to get into, but with the right people it's a great puzzle-action-expericence.To be honest, first time I played (when I didn't know what I was getting into) I had a bad time. The genre-mix of puzzle-coop-arena-hack'n'slash makes it hard to wrap ones head around and certainly not for everyone. That said, when you give it a fair chance you will have a good time with this game.With three players we completed the first one and a half worlds and with the right mindset the game is really enjoyable. A lot of communication happening on the couch to figure out the levels. It is collective puzzle solving, while fighting hordes of creeps and organizing your positions to get the 'damn orb' to the right place - great concept, well executed.Furthermore the leveling-system has a nice lerning-curve and let's you personalize your playstyle and offers lots of possibilities to adjust to the challenges.Nevertheless these flaws are in the game (just so you're prepared for them):The front-loaded tutorial was kind of confusing and for some mechanics I didn't get what it wanted to teach me.Sometimes the game forces you to go back to previous levels and complete some challenges to progress. I'd rather liked to make those completely optional.oh, and the dialogs... no, simply no

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												I wanted a game I could couch co-op with my girlfriend when we're in the mood for hack'n'slashing.Forced covered this perfectly, but also turned out to be so much more. The puzzles weave through the action seamlessly, creating a challenging but exhilarating atmosphere. The necessary tactical reconsideration after being defeated multiple times means replaying levels doesn't get boring. The levelling system is a cruel but perfect motivator, pushing you to visit forgotten torturous levels in the hope for one more gem.If you're playing by yourself, this will be a challenging but rewarding experience.If you're playing with a friend, this will be a heap of fun, but may cause you to slap each other.Very dissappointed the sequel will not be multiplayer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27
												TLDR; Kind of tricky to get into, but with the right people it's a great puzzle-action-expericence.To be honest, first time I played (when I didn't know what I was getting into) I had a bad time. The genre-mix of puzzle-coop-arena-hack'n'slash makes it hard to wrap ones head around and certainly not for everyone. That said, when you give it a fair chance you will have a good time with this game.With three players we completed the first one and a half worlds and with the right mindset the game is really enjoyable. A lot of communication happening on the couch to figure out the levels. It is collective puzzle solving, while fighting hordes of creeps and organizing your positions to get the 'damn orb' to the right place - great concept, well executed.Furthermore the leveling-system has a nice lerning-curve and let's you personalize your playstyle and offers lots of possibilities to adjust to the challenges.Nevertheless these flaws are in the game (just so you're prepared for them):The front-loaded tutorial was kind of confusing and for some mechanics I didn't get what it wanted to teach me.Sometimes the game forces you to go back to previous levels and complete some challenges to progress. I'd rather liked to make those completely optional.oh, and the dialogs... no, simply no

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This is one of the few games in my Steam library that I have actually gotten my wife to play with me, so that gets it a positive review right there. But seriously this game is tons of fun. It's not exactly story-rich, but thats not really something you look for in this style of game. The four characters to pick from are a good representation of different play styles, and the variety of spells allow for some customization to that as well. The levels are more than just navigating through the map; the puzzles are very challenging at times, and the boss levels are actually tough. To me, those two points determine the success or failure of this style of game, and Forced is a winner in both categories.Pros: Challenging puzzlesTough boss levelsCons:Thin story (but seriously, who cares about that? That's like complaining that the Dota 2 lore is weak.)One more thing: go to BetaDwarf's site, and read about how while programming this game, they literally lived in part of a college that wasn't being used for almost a year before they got caught and kicked out! It's hilarious, and there's no way you won't buy the game after that. Better yet, buy the 4-pack and your friends will be FORCED to play with you!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Pretty fun, unsurprisingly. But it's also not very addicting.I would compare this game to the old Gauntlet Legends games, but with more emphasis on puzzle solving and teamwork. The addictiveness of typical RPG's (like leveling up and collecting items) is kind of absent in this game. It's fun having the flexibility to select your skills and character at any time, but the skills are more like "powerups" that you unlock through the game.Overall, I think it has good depth, but the emphasis on puzzle solving makes it more casual, and not really a game to get hooked on.If I had to give it a vague rating, I would say 7/10 and recommended.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Decent premise, unique gameplay mechanics, very tight controls plus co-op!  This is in the same vein as Magicka and Torchlight.  It has fewer bugs and much tighter controls than Magicka.  It is not nearly as deep in terms of skill tree etc as Torchlight and it is rather linear, but I do appreciate how the classes play off one another.  While torchlight will throw half a dozen usable skills at you which may do very similar things, FORCED lets you pick a couple skills and use them in what seems like a half dozen ways.  While I miss the stats of Torchlight, this is a very satisfying little game.  Get on sale if you can, but a thumbs up regardless.  8.5/10

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												I thought my friends and I made a great team. I thought we could tackle this game like a well oiled machine, just as we have with any other game.No. I was wrong and for my arrogance I paid the price. But my friends and I are closer now for this game showed us the worst in eachother. Now our teamwork has skyrocketed.This game is hard. It will challenge you mentally and socially. Your ability to communicate ideas on the flaw will be sharpened or you will fail. This is a top down RPG with a stronger focus on classes that play off eachother and not so much on customization. You play through a quick and easy tutorial and then are introduced to the main area where you will select which level you want to play, much like Crash Bandicoot 2: Cortext Strikes back. This game has a large focus on cohesion and team work and less on hacking and griding through hundreds of monsters. I strongly recommend this game because I have never had so much fun getting my♥♥♥♥♥kicked.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												20 June 2014It's with Great shame that i will advise not to bother with Forced yet.This is one of the greatest ideas and the game itself feels amazing to Play, so why the Negative?Forced is currently suffering from a Number of bad Game Design Choices and certain Bugs.Myself and a 2nd player reached the second boss with a few bugs but nothing horrible.We were pleased with the game and wanted to go further, but the the only reason we got as far as we did (level 2) is that the ease of the game covered the design flaws to that point. When the complexity (not difficulty) ramps up you begin to realise the flaws.    Flaw 1: The Camera is Horrible. This game is centered around it's co-op mode and it could be fun, but the game currently runs on a single camera system that always keeps you, you parner and or the boss in it's view. This is fine until the level complexity increases at which point characters can become very hard to see and the camera distances itself massivly. A bug also occurs here where you can actually walk your character off camera, and if your team members are fighting or solving in opposite corners you can't see youself at all, causing all sorts of issues. Local Camera is heavily needed, keep the player and the Boss (for example) and fix the edge Clipping, letting your party do as they please, Colored Player indicators are amazing in that situation to determine where people are, or even a very simple minimap if its THAT complicated.    Flaw 2: That leads me nicely onto this. The company have decided to op out of being able to walk through your enemys. This feels good until you encounter more then 2-3 at once, at which Point they surround you, locking you in place as you can't Push them. There are knockback mechanics and escape mechanics you can choose for your character. But now you find yourself in a position where fun or damage talents are unusable because you need movement survival and escape for when you get Trapped or Knocked back. This ALSO has a bug of its own, where EVERY ability that can be classed as an escape or survival can just ranomdly not work (Non more evident than using the shield weapons 'dash' ability, where it often takes you no-where, despite showing the animations of you moving, or even teleports you back to where you started)    Flaw 3: The gameplay lends itself to heavy hack and slash combat that's real fun. But more enemys means you quickly start to realise an issue. You can't Heal. 2/4 classes have heals, one is decent but on a LONG Cooldown (And interuptable via knockback), and the other is a heal over time effect with a speed boost, that whilst being mandetory is only useful for the speed, and requires spamming. The only other way to heal is the Poles you can drift the Orb over, which also require spamming in order to stand a chance. What this leads to is a Cluster F*** of enemys who synergise very badly and do nothing but follow you in a Lump. You find yourself unable to find many safe attack areas and spend the majority of combat running around avoiding the fight because you can't heal, or because the enemys invincible until the boss gives you a charge to defeat him (a charge you can only call to you, and that almost Kills you if it detonates nearby).All in all, this game has the potential to be one of the best co-ops out there, These issues however make it frustrating and awkward to play. After a lot of frustrating game mechanics issues, we left Forced behind at level 2. No amount of skill or learning will get you past RNG when your dash's, escapes and heals don't work. No amount of skill or enjoment will get you past camera fails, where you cannot see your Chatacer.Current? 3/10These simple issues Fixed? 7-8/10 EASILY.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Recommended for the great control and game mechanics. The controls are on par with, or even succeeds, the best in the genre (which would be Diablo III I suppose)... they are very snappy. Ok, maybe calling the orb to your location could be smoother, that is the only thing I don't like.FORCED differs itself from every other ARPG by not having any grinding... and also not having equipment or experience points. If this is good or bad, I don't know, but it makes for a different game.You unlock abilities by completing trials. Each trial is a level with monsters and sometimes puzzles.You get one point for completing the level.You get one point for completing the level within a specified amount of time, andyou get one point for completing a unique challenge for each level.However, by not having the grind, there is a burden on the developers to provide a lot more content than normally in the genre. You finish each area much faster, and there is no value for the player in going back once the trials are completed... and the amount of content is OK, but not great.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Forced is a great ARPG game that features 4 classes. Each class has different unlockable passive and active abilities.  You collect Gems  by completing various tasks within each level and that's how you level up in the game. You play as gladiators (the Storm Bow, the Volcanic Hammer, the Spirit Knives and the Frost Shield) who try to find their freedom and are aided by a spirit called Balfus. Balfus and the fact that you can use him by calling him toward you, lighting torches (and some other things) is the main reason this game stands out as it adds some great and diverse tactics that always serve towards your goal of earning the 3 Gems each level (arena) has to offer. The story is not this game's strong point as the plot is fairly simple. You play as a gladiator that has been FORCED (pun intended) to fight in arenas and Balfus guides you through it and you ultimately have to become a free man.All in all the game is really tactical and has a lot of strategic depth, granted you want to 100% it with friends.The multiplayer is really fun and I recommend you get 3 or 4 friends to play with. The game provides great puzzles and fun combat and with good co-operation it's bound to be a truly fun experience! I thoroughly recommend it!

Not worth it, even with the -50% off deal, until they patch a jarring amounts of connection issues, missing textures from menus, and god knows how much many other, underlying issues waiting for players who waste their times going through the tutorial levels...The gameplay is basically mild puzzles smashed together with arena beat-em-up gameplay, where you'll be fighting against the clock (and spastic game bugs) to deal with blowing up statues, smashing into enemies in a poor excuse for a cooperative game, where player actions have scarce effect on teamplay, other than to screw with each others plans to pass the glowing puzzle ball around, causing much frustration.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This was a failed attempt to merge 3 different genres: RPG, Top down hack-and-slash, and co-op puzzle solving. Its claim to fame is that players are supposed to cooperate in puzzle solving while being assaulted by waves of enemies. However, these systems work against each other. The AI enemies are not threatening enough to pose as a threat; they become a mere annoyance as you try to solve the puzzles to finish the level. Likewise, the co-op puzzles aren't very good either; instructions and tutorials are vague, but if you manage to guess-and-check your way to the solution, you'll find many levels that repeat the same type of puzzle. The co-op system doesn't really work with puzzles; you'll be fighting your friends for your idea of problem solving, instead of collaborating to complete the challenge. Connectivity is horrid, and although the game features 4 different classes, they feel somewhat similar against the same dull foes. 3/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												A fun and challenging co-op action/puzzle game. It's not really an RPG such as Torchlight II or Diablo, but is instead focused on having four different weapon classes to take on challenges known as "Trials". Completing each trial will unlock crystals that automatically unlock abilities across your weapons. You can change abilities and weapons before any trial, so no need to worry about taking the wrong things. There is also this orb that you can control and is the main aspect of pretty much all puzzles, and even some combat.Bought during sale. I really enjoyed this game.  Highly reccomended to play if you have any friends to play with, as it can be a bit dull alone. It performed better than my expectations, and was well worth my money.Obligatory pro's and cons:+ Really fun for 2-4 players+ Handles multiplayer scaling and progresses in difficulty very well.+ Fun combat and classes+ OH GOSH SO MANY ENEMIES TO KEEP IN CHECK WHILE TRYING TO CONTROL THIS ORB AND BEING CHASED BY A GIANT SPINNING DEATH LAZOR- A bit dull alone- Slight lagspikes at times during multiplayer (could be my internet, though)- Orb-controlling is slightly annoying when you're not co-operating properly in multiplayer.- OH GOSH SO MANY ENEMIES TO KEEP IN CHECK WHILE HAVING TO CONTROL THIS ORB ACROSS A GIANT SPINNING DEATH LAZOR FIFTEEN TIMESFinal score: 8/10 so far. Reccomended to buy during sales, but 14€ is worth it if you're into this kind of games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I absolutely adore this game. Plenty of people have already mentioned that it is a beautiful and challenging arena-style game, putting a lot of focus on teamwork and using different tactics to defeat different opponents while solving puzzles at the same time. But what I like most is that before every fight, you can choose anew which one of the four weapons (claws, shield, hammer or bow and arrow) you want to use and which passive and active skills you want to assign to it. The skills for all weapons are unlocked simultaneously, so you don't end up with a level 10 hammer and a level 1 shield. Neither will you regret your choice of character five hours into the game, or wonder if you shouldn't have focused on a different skill tree after all.My friends and I bought the game when it was on sale because of the sob story on reddit. Having played it now, I would pay full price for it without hesitating. I can only whole-heartedly recommend Forced to anybody!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Overall: 9 out of 10I've been looking for a good couch co-op hack'n'slash for a while. So many are shy of satisfying.Fortunately, this one steps up.Levels and puzzles have more variation and inginuity to them that your typical game. It had me looking forward to the next map.Persistent character gain (skills and skill slots) unlock via gaining gems (basically exp). Beating a single map feels like a win. (i dislike the modern fad of games resetting every time)Levels are replayable and have very decent challenges to gain additional gems. I usually tend to avoid this in similar game, but found it reasonable and enjoyable in this game.Gameplay definitely encourages cooperation. while i think it would suffer single player, 2-player was a blast and it is supposed to tailor difficulty to the number of players.Additional notes: *aside from explosive level objects, there is no player damage (As i definitely prefer!).*difficulty is generally moderate to a bit challenging. The game sets you up to have consistent challenge, driving you to stay alive. You will die, but it will be fun trying not to. (I am definitely not into "hardcore mode" games. I want a reasonable challenge, not a chore or test in patience). A reasonable gamer should expect to die a couple times and then succeed on most levels. Children may have a hard time.*the game also feels much more polished than many recent games. (no pixel=style laziness, and no half thought out levels)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is a very challenging action game with a lot of puzzles in the mix.  Not the most difficult game you could be playing but still very difficult, Forced has you playing through a variety of challenges, from puzzles to boss battles to time limits.  This was my first game to get 100% achievement status on, and I got that status within 12 hours, so obviously, the game is short.  However, I have to admit the game was absurdly challenging and required a lot of patience and planning to play it properly.Keyboard/mouse controls are great, so I did not bother trying out a gamepad, but there is Xbox 360 controller support.  The space key is used for multiple actions, however, and I often had to restart levels because I accidentally called the orb when I was trying to skip dialogue.  Not a big deal, mind you.  I just found that slightly annoying.The game could be longer, and I wish there were more character customization options.  There are no visual customizations, but what I would really like to see are some more skill and stat choices.  I felt like only a few of the skills and stats were worth using.  Overall, the game was a lot of fun, and it is worth full price to me, but it is far from a perfected experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												FORCED has made my buddy and I quite happy.It feels like the developers had fun making the game, and it shows.The gameplay is very reminiscent of Gauntlet: Legends:+isometric camera+hack and slash combat+'level up' system in unlocking new skills+fast and well paced+The campaign is a little cheesy, but charming in it's own way-graphics aren't impressive+but it makes the game easy to run+and the art direction more than makes up for it+inspired and creative puzzles keep you thinking, but don't slow the game down enough to where you're bored and feel you're in a puzzle-only game.You're constantly working out defeating small waves of monsters, dancing around the map's pitfalls, and working out how to solve puzzles.-some of the challenges can be tedius and seem unresponsive, though it's more an issue of getting used to hit boxes and mechanics.I strongly recommend this game to small groups of friends who are looking for a fun and challenging multiplayer game.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Quality Action RPG: check.Quality puzzles: check.Quality skill and build diversity: check.Quality trolling potential: oh yes.There is only one main component for puzzles: a spirit guide you move around by pressing space. This means cooperation is EVERYTHING in multiplayer mode; this may be why you don't see many public games in the co-op lobby. It's just too damn easy to troll because everyone doesn't have their own spirit guide, but then that could make FORCED game-breakingly easy.Also, you have a lot of interesting options in how you build your character, but the game doesn't save your build which is pretty lame. If you could actually save your build without having to remember your ideal skill setup for each weapon, FORCED would be hands-down one of the best ARPG's in years. That aside, the game still has plenty to offer and is definitely worth your time. Plus it's incredibly fun to play with friends (that actually want to help you win the game, because it is so easy to troll).
