content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Forced is one of the best unity games ever made. an enjoyable coop game with some fairly difficult challenges and enjoyable combat. -pros: Sound and music           A plethera of interesting settings and objectives           Some tough and unique bosses           Good voice acting for what little there is           Spirit Mentor mechanics           Combat and progression are fun and encourage you to be creative           Local Coop-cons: The rogue and archer classes are far better than shield and hammer           Some of the completion times use to get crystals for new abilities are somewhat impossible to get           Playing with the M&K after an hour and a half or so starts lagging the game           no pvp It's still one of the best coop games to pick up and I would recommend to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Forced is one of those games to make you rage uncontrollably. Its difficult, sometimes obtuse, and requires impeccable communication. And its damn fun. This isn't a game you can autopilot through. You have to be on your A game 100% of the time, which for me meant taking a break every couple of levels. However the completion of a challenge is extremely rewarding.Unlike many hack and slashers, this game does not focus on equipment or leveling skills, instead it provides skills that have distinct tradeoffs against other skills and may need to be optimized between levels. Your characters never get more health or do more damage, but they do get skills that combo together to do more damage. Art style was basic but competent, character readability was very good. Sound was basic but competent. I got this game as early access and was impressed by the improvement and overall progress that the devs accomplished. The game has online coop and local coop with up to 4 players. While you can play by yourself, its singnificantly more fun with friends.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Overall: 9 out of 10I've been looking for a good couch co-op hack'n'slash for a while. So many are shy of satisfying.Fortunately, this one steps up.Levels and puzzles have more variation and inginuity to them that your typical game. It had me looking forward to the next map.Persistent character gain (skills and skill slots) unlock via gaining gems (basically exp). Beating a single map feels like a win. (i dislike the modern fad of games resetting every time)Levels are replayable and have very decent challenges to gain additional gems. I usually tend to avoid this in similar game, but found it reasonable and enjoyable in this game.Gameplay definitely encourages cooperation. while i think it would suffer single player, 2-player was a blast and it is supposed to tailor difficulty to the number of players.Additional notes: *aside from explosive level objects, there is no player damage (As i definitely prefer!).*difficulty is generally moderate to a bit challenging. The game sets you up to have consistent challenge, driving you to stay alive. You will die, but it will be fun trying not to. (I am definitely not into "hardcore mode" games. I want a reasonable challenge, not a chore or test in patience). A reasonable gamer should expect to die a couple times and then succeed on most levels. Children may have a hard time.*the game also feels much more polished than many recent games. (no pixel=style laziness, and no half thought out levels)

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												BetaDwarf guys decided to do something we haven't seen in a while; create a new genre, and they did it really good! Ok, not exactly new, it's more a hybrid between classic ARPGs and puzzle games, but it plays very differently from both...Actually, you play through many different "arenas" (trials) trying to pass their main challenge thus providing yourself a crystal (something like leveling)... Each trial, has 3 crystals, one for completing it, one for special challenge within it, and one for completing it in a specified time frame... Completing a trial is the part of the game you will have problems with, but completing the special challenge and time frame is almost impossible, and you will often need to level up (gain more crystals) and come back later to do it...Gameplay consists of classic hack-n-slash, fast reflexes for dodging and puzzle elements. Puzzles are not hard, but you're always multitasking, killing monsters, running and using a spirit Balfus to activate everything you need (be it healing, damaging or puzzle element)...Story is not spectacular, but it makes sense which is not easy for games like these, graphics style is nice and colourful (the latter can be a problem sometimes) and gameplay is interesting, dynamic and often frustrating...And, that frustration can sometimes be the biggest problem this game has... It is hard... extremely hard! Unforgiving, and painful... But, for the same reason really, really rewarding!Another downside is the necessity to use online feature even for local co-op?! Very bad :(Either way, it's a fantastic game, and easy recommendation!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												Up front, Forced appears to do a good job of blending Guantlet arcade-style smash'm up with ARPG elements--added to with a touch of simple puzzle solving. Sadly, the game idea that Forced is needs much more...For Single-Players, or Solo-Play:The attempt at a story is more of a hinderance and should've been left out almost all together. The general direction in design is pretty spotty and left me feeling non-plussed several times as I attempted to learn one mechanic or another. The challenges are a bit too tightly setup, and are limited in scope. Thus, completing challenges unlocks abilites, and so you find yourself "forced" to wait for much good deal of the fun the game can provide, repeating the same stages over and over. Also, a key element in the game, your spirit mentor, could be so much more interesing. Last but not least, the graphics really could be better, indie or not.As much as Forced is a solid idea, the production quality and execution are both sadly lackluster...and that voice acting...yikes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is a very challenging action game with a lot of puzzles in the mix.  Not the most difficult game you could be playing but still very difficult, Forced has you playing through a variety of challenges, from puzzles to boss battles to time limits.  This was my first game to get 100% achievement status on, and I got that status within 12 hours, so obviously, the game is short.  However, I have to admit the game was absurdly challenging and required a lot of patience and planning to play it properly.Keyboard/mouse controls are great, so I did not bother trying out a gamepad, but there is Xbox 360 controller support.  The space key is used for multiple actions, however, and I often had to restart levels because I accidentally called the orb when I was trying to skip dialogue.  Not a big deal, mind you.  I just found that slightly annoying.The game could be longer, and I wish there were more character customization options.  There are no visual customizations, but what I would really like to see are some more skill and stat choices.  I felt like only a few of the skills and stats were worth using.  Overall, the game was a lot of fun, and it is worth full price to me, but it is far from a perfected experience.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												The story may be terrible with voice acting to match but by god does it have a wonderful game underneath it all. Surprisingly well done co-op. The levels adapt to how many people are playing in such a way that it doesn't become a hindrance to have your allies nor does it become too easy. FORCED hit a wonderful balance; for the most part. There were a few parts that weren't as well thought out but overall this is a good time.If you're looking for a fun, challenging, cooperative game that involves killing things and solving puzzles; this is a good choice. Just... skip all the exposition and story. Which, coming from someone who will play through terrible games because they have an amazing story hidden underneath, is saying something.

content:
Posted: February 10
												Forced is a interestingly unique Gauntlet Legends style top down game, with a lot of puzzle-esque elements and battles to attend to at the same time. You play as one of 4 unique characters each with their own strengths and weaknesses.It's heavily intended to be played with co-op, with each additional player a scaling difficulty setting. And much like Magicka, the ways in which each player dies is more hilarious than the last. Me and my buddies have had way too many laughs at the expense of our lesser game inclined friends, throwing them into the game with a basic knowledge base of the games mechanics and watching them try their hardest to no avail.Pros:+ Up to 4 player Co-Op fun+ Hilarious gameplay + Puzzle Mechanics incorporated into the battle system+ Unique characters that suits each playstyleCons:- Some challanges are extremely difficult and potentially unencouraging if you're an achievement hunterTL;DR:9/10 Top down Gauntlet Style Co-Op game with puzzle mechanics

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												This is a pretty unique hack and slash game. There is no loot to gather or quests to complete. You run in and complete each dungeon utilizing 4 different classes. I think the game is best played in co-op as you need to pass the orb (Balthus) through objects across the screen to activate. I beat this playing locally with 2-4 people at a time. Difficulty and # of enemies scales with more players. Abilities of different classes complement each other pretty well (healing, taunting, invisibility, etc.). It was fun to play locally and would play through the game again switching up classes and abilities. I give this game a 9/10 but only for the reason that there is no DLC or updates. If there were more boss fights then this game could have more replayability. 9/10

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												This is not a hack n' slash action game with puzzle elements. It's timed ball-moving puzzles with an action game built around it. Nine times out of ten your absolute first priority is moving a ball through the right hoops to give it the right property and perform the right action.Yes, enemies will spawn all the time. Yes, you have a skill system that let's you grow more powerful as you progress. Yes, there is some great synergy between the four classes if you go at it in co-op. Still, this never changes the fact that the only reason you want to become a better fighter is to be able to move your ball faster and safer while the enemies mob you.This makes it an action game where the combat is a nuisance to your great ball-moving fun times.Add to this that everyone in your party has the same ammount of control over this sphere of godly importance. If you want to bicker with your friends about balls in the wrong place this is your game!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Looks really good in the videos and pictures they have up on the steam store but like Frozen Synapse, the gameplay is pretty different than what you see, except in Forced's case, not as different than in Frozen Synapse. Forced is a team game where you try to complete puzzles and fight monsters to go on to the next level and progress through the storyline, however, there is barely any people online to play with. This sucks because most of the challenges that you need to complete require the help of another person. In short, this game is boring to play by yourself as you'll find the story is very linear and boring, while the actual gameplay, which is intended for group play, will be frustrating. I'd recommend playing this game in a group but if you're more of a lone wolf, don't pick it up. I got bored after the 2 days I spent with it. I would return it if i could since it's that much of a kiddy game

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game is stupid. Requires ridiculous amount of teamwork, which doesn't really work out at all. Having to control an orb, splitting control among four people, and using it to do damn near everything in the game is one of the dumbest ideas a developer could have had. I can't stress enought that being FORCED (haha) to cooperate with teammates who may just be a "little slow" is terrible. Need a heal? Use the ball. Need to get an enemy from slamming your face into the earth? Use the ball. Two players need to do both at once? Yea, go f*** yourselves, only one person is making it out. Enemies aren't balanced and you'll find yourself repeating the same mission over and over becuase a laser beam keeps obliterating your pathetic, wimpy, body. Classes are crappy and you cant double up on them, nor does the game seem to give a damn whether or not the missions are completable. Save your money and spend it on something better, like a hammer to bash in your own skull if you decide to buy this. Only good news I have for this is that I'm not the one who bought it, and a friend bought a four pack. Note: if your friend buys this, bash HIS/HER head in instead.

												One of the better co-op games I've played. Definitely the best co-op indie game I've played. So awesome, in fact, that everyone I play it with avoids continuing to play with me! Honestly, though, the element of interacting with each other via using the orb to interact with the environment in order to navigate the map and defeat creatures and bosses... it's ingenious (I realize that was a confusing sentence but perhaps it helps properly emphasize the complexity of the game). This game gets a solid 9.5/10. It would get a 10/10 if I could find the right friends to finish the game with! I really want to beat it!

content:

												Forced is not-terrible/pretty good aRPG in a very similar style and vein as Torchlight with some added enjoyable puzzle solving, but it has questionable difficulty spikes in single-player and appears to be more tuned for co-op play. content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Refreshingly challenging and enjoyable.  The class and level designs are very well tuned for the sake of being challenging.  Each class has its own unique playstyle, and several builds to try and play around.  The level design clearly shows how much effort the developers put into this game because each and every single level is unique, and even unique with respect to the number of players.Don't worry about the difficulty.  I guarantee you can SOLO clear every challenge with only trial and error in game. (Yes, I have done that myself, without using any guide.)  Everything is managable if you know what you need to do and what you are doing.  Analyze the level, plan your action, customize your character build, then execute it with, um, some reflex.I truly recommend this game.  It has been so long since I last enjoy action/puzzle game this much, especially in multiplayer mode.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												My advice: DO NOT buy this game. The description is misleading: there is no RPG element to this game. Nor is singleplayer actually possible, despite it being an option: you simply cannot complete many of the challenges. All it is a coop puzzle arena, and even that I would not mind if the coop worked. It does not. Well, it does for a while, but if you get more than, say, 20 enemies onscreen at one time, something breaks in the game's netcode and everyone who is not hosting suddenly gets massive lag. Looks like GPU lag almost. So we tried different host. Same thing, the host always seeing the game fine, the guests getting 1-5 FPS during intense fights. TL:DR This is a multiplayer only game that does not support multiplayer, avoid at all cost.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												I bought this with a friend, and we had a blast. The payoff here is great; I received immense satisfaction from figuring out puzzles and performing insanely powerful attacks by coordinating with someone else. I firmly believe the best way to experience FORCED is with a dedicated partner or three so that you can complete the entire game with the same group of people.That being said, the puzzles are not very complicated at all. The true difficulty will be in attempting Challenges (finishing a level while achieving a specific goal) and Time Trials (finishing a level within a certain amount of time). Completing Challenges and Time Trials will require attempt after attempt after attempt. Beta Dwarf could have planned for this a bit better and not put as many long cut scenes in inconvenient places, but you can skip after a few seconds. Nevertheless, Challenges and Time Trials give this title some serious replayability. The game is fun enough to justify multiple (read: dozens of) consecutive attempts. I did not feel like I had completed the game until I had all 75 gems, which took roughly 47 hours.The online infrastructure can be a little rough. We had to exit out of the game and set it back up once every 1-1.5 hours or so due to game crashing bugs or unresponsive controls. However, it is important to note that the gameplay made it worth it. We kept coming back to it because of the addictive gem collecting and the fun, rewarding combat system. Mercifully, Beta Dwarf has insured that load times are minimal and creating/joining a game are very simple. This means setting up a game is a trivial affair, and the inconvenience of the (infrequent) game crashing bugs is mitigated. The combat system is the crux of the gameplay. Basic attacks leave enemies with marks. Depending on what abilities your character has, marks can cause special attacks to do more damage. The abilities you equip your character with (up to 3 active and 3 passive) give you perks and access to powerful attacks. Discovering synergy between passives and actives is one of the most compelling reasons to keep playing the game and adds strategy to what would otherwise be a mindless beat-em-up.Gems enable you to unlock abilities and equip yourself with more abilities. There are 75 in the game, three for each level (1 for beating the level, 1 for completing the challenge, 1 for beating the Time Trial). Every few gems you score, you unlock a new ability, which adds to the sense of progress throughout the game and encourages you to experiment with your new found awesomeness.It is important to note that the experience I am praising arose from me from having a friend that was dedicated to playing the game. I cannot speak to the game's singleplayer mode, but I also cannot see it providing the same sense of accomplishment, nor can I see it motivating me in the same way to attempt each level the insane number of times I did. It always helped to have someone to talk to and discuss strategies with. With that understood, I give it...8.7/10I hope Beta Dwarf keeps making awesome multiplayer games with over-the-top bosses.TL;DR : Great gameplay, adequate online connectivity, don't get it if you don't have friends.

												FORCED combines a few things that every player likes: undeads, powerful skills and a shiny blue bubble named Balfus that acts as your mentor. content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												2013/11/01三人COOPにてプレイ、約7～8時間。(シングルは未プレイ)スクリーンショットではハクスラめいた構図ですが、トレハンの要素はなく、若干の成長要素があるものの純粋なアクションパズルゲーム。個人的にはMagicaにBlizzardイズムを合わせたようなゲームと感じました。プレイヤーは4種のRoleを選択し、しゃべる珠Balfusと協力しながら各Levelをクリアしていきます。各Role共通のシステムとしてMarker(コンボポイント)があり、上手く蓄積とフィニッシュを織り交ぜることで敵を殲滅していきます。戦闘バランス自体は絶妙で、各Roleの特徴をしっかり活かしてカバーしあわないと割とあっさり死にます……バカゲーかと思いきやかなりしっかりと作られたゲームで高評価ですが、ラスボスが機能停止するバグと一部リトライ時に3Pが地面に埋まるバグがマイナス。メインテーマとラスボスのBGMはかなりアツイ。個人的評価ゲーム性　　  85点ストーリー　 　70点BGM　 　　　70点コスパ　　　  55点バグや謎仕様-15点総合評価　　 70点(意外な良作、バグや謎仕様が惜しい)以下各Role-赤(ハンマー)MeleeのAoEやAuraがウリのパワーファイター。一定時間溜めることで強力なスイングができるが、移動スキルや脱出スキルが乏しい。-青(盾)ChargeやAoEStunを得意とする。一定時間毎にShieldがあがり攻撃をBlockできるようになるが、殲滅力に欠けるTankタイプ。-緑(ダガー)素早い攻撃とフィニッシュムーブの回転率で単体ダメージを叩き出す純粋なDPSタイプ。軽快な挙動も魅力。-黄(弓)得物通りの遠距離型。チャージショットや設置型のHeal、ChannelAoEなど強力な攻撃手段を持つ。

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Uppers: Intense, surprisingly intricate action co-op that works with three or four players and has a clever push-pull teamwork gimmick. In its best moments is like doing a really good raid in an MMO but without the hassle and poopsocking. Difficulty can be fine-tuned by doing challenges or choosing particular classes (eg no archer for Graw).Downers: Some strange performance issues - sometimes stutters a lot for no obvious reason, which can be a death sentence. Understandably cheap feeling to the presentation. Possibly a bit short. You will curse Balfus' name.The Bottom Line: Co-op improves any video game, and FORCED uses it in an effective, rather innovative way. It's tough but rarely frustrating, and features satisfying/comical teamwork. Grab your mic and fight the spitters.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												A fantastic couch co-op game! Not enough games have this feature anymore but nothing beats getting some friends around, hooking up 4 controllers and having a laugh. The game looks beautiful, especially as you get through the game and explore different scenery. You play through "trials" which are small levels which feature puzzles, combat and strategy. By completing these you earn crystals which you use to unlock skills with your character class which you can change at any time.  Each trial has 3 crystals to obtain, one for completing the level, one for completing a said challenge within the trial and one for compelting the trial within a time limit. Some of the challanges are impossible to get at a lower level which means you need revisit levels you have done before to increase your crystal total.A fun game with depth that I did not expect. I expected this to be twin stick shooter but turned out to be so much more!8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												So bought this game as a 4 pack with some friends. Totally worth it! It's a sorta hack/slash rpg'ish puzzle game. You control 1 of 4 different characters (hammer, bow, shield, daggers) each has their own set of skills, passives, and playstyles. You work with your friends to navigate innovative maps and figure out puzzles all with the help of a little orb spirt guy. Every person can call this orb to their position so it can be trolly if everyone is spamming. It requires a great deal of communication as it sometimes requires you to bounce the orb from person to person but without letting it hit objects (part of the puzzle). I highly recommend you pick this up in a 4 pack and play with friends over voice chat as it can be very fun, quirky, rewarding, and frustrating all in one but there is sense of accomplishment similar to when you first beat a boss in an MMO when you nail a puzzle while 3 of your friends are dead and you are teetering on life. The simple combat systems works perfectly as there is plenty of other object happening on the screen to keep you active and always thinking.There isn't a game out there like this on the market that I am aware. Anyone who plays with friends should pick this up.

												FORCED (Slightly Better Edition) is a fun combat/strategy multiplayer game with up to 3 friends, and I recommend it!+ Combat is fast-paced and simple, with enough difference in the enemies' approaches to keep it engaging.+ Puzzle elements CHALLENGE players to work together and think through obstacles.+ Different elemental archtypes to choose from (ice, earth, fire, air) with multiple skill choices to equip as you level up.- Occasionally blindsides the players with problems that require trial and error (or pure luck) to solve.- Puzzles become frustrating without good communication and coordination between teammates.- Low replayability.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Great game at a great price!  I've read some reviews that the co-op isn't playable, however I've only played the single player/campaign mode and find the game excellent!Forced combines Diablo-type hack & slash with some very unique puzzles and difficult challenges. The casual player could try and hack & slash their way through the game, but for more hardcore gamers there are times to beat and challenges to conquer on every stage which require a lot more thinking and strategy.  Another great feature is that most levels usually take under 5 minutes which make this a great game to sit down to if you don't have hours and hours to play.This is a really well made indie game that I'd say competes with the big market games.  In fact, I bought Diablo 3: Reaper of Souls about the same time as this and haven't touched D3 since.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Forced is a neat little Action RPG puzzle couch co-op game. Maybe a cross between DotA/LoL + WoW + Portal 2. In short you are solving puzzles in a dungeon/instances with your partner while mobs attack you.Imagine sitting together with your 360 controllers (or on skype) running around avoiding a laser beam while trying to kill mobs that are attacking you. Meanwhile your co-op partner is aligning Balfus (a floating orb) in a straight line towards you and screaming at you to pull the orb so that it goes through a shrine that stops a deadly mists that is slowly filling the dungeon. You pull the orb towards you but just when the orb is about to turn off the the mist your co-op partner gets pinned by a mob he didn't avoid and needs to call the orb back to him to free himself. Now the mist is out of control and your coop partner is low on health. This is a basic scenario in Forced.The game has several dungeons/levels that you have to complete. Each dungeon rewards a total of 3 crystals. One for completing the dungeon, one for a speed/timed run and one for completing with a special requirement (e.g no healing, not getting hit by a special mob, etc).Before each dungeon you choose to play one of four available classes. A warrior, rogue, hunter and a tank. Every class has two talent trees: One tree for active talents and one for passive talents. As you earn more crystals you unlock more of your talents.  You get to choose 3 active and 3 passive skills. That means that you have 4 buttons to press: One for basic attack and three for active talents.This is a game where you can play competitvely and min/max what class and what spec to play for eac dungeon. make a tactic and practice exucuting it impeccably or you can grab a 360 controller and have fun with your girlfriend on the couch.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												So bought this game as a 4 pack with some friends. Totally worth it! It's a sorta hack/slash rpg'ish puzzle game. You control 1 of 4 different characters (hammer, bow, shield, daggers) each has their own set of skills, passives, and playstyles. You work with your friends to navigate innovative maps and figure out puzzles all with the help of a little orb spirt guy. Every person can call this orb to their position so it can be trolly if everyone is spamming. It requires a great deal of communication as it sometimes requires you to bounce the orb from person to person but without letting it hit objects (part of the puzzle). I highly recommend you pick this up in a 4 pack and play with friends over voice chat as it can be very fun, quirky, rewarding, and frustrating all in one but there is sense of accomplishment similar to when you first beat a boss in an MMO when you nail a puzzle while 3 of your friends are dead and you are teetering on life. The simple combat systems works perfectly as there is plenty of other object happening on the screen to keep you active and always thinking.There isn't a game out there like this on the market that I am aware. Anyone who plays with friends should pick this up.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												In co-op, this game is amazing. Simple enough to pick up quickly but has enough depth to keep your attention, whether just trying to get through the levels for the first time or going back for the challenge objectives and the time objectives, there is a lot of fun to be had here with a friend or 3. Graphics are pretty enough, and the progression is handled well. Analyzing the mission and changing your loadouts to best suit what you are going for (speed run, certain objectives, etc) has me coming back for more every day. Highly recommend, if you don't have any friends playing it is highly worth buying the pack and giving someone a copy just to play with. Lots of fun and encourages good communication and problem solving to play at a high level.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Forced is a neatly polished game which will bring a couple of hours of fun with you and your friends. At first the game teaches you the simple mechanics as you learn each of the classes. As you progress into the next world, the game does get harder, with enemies being tougher and puzzles more challenging, but as you master that world, the next is even more difficult, where you and your friends have to work very hard to complete each challenge. Has a very nice levelling and upgrade system, could use some work, balancing, etc. The only problem I have, is Singleplayer and Multiplayer difficulty scaling. Want to play past the second world by yourself? Well that is near impossible. I am not sure if this has been fixed yet, but BetaDwarf should consider to make the game easier (lower enemy spawns, health, damage, etc.) when by yourself. Also I've noticed an uneven scaling with two to three to four players. I believe three is the easiest. Other than that you'll probably snag a good 5-20 hours based on how much you enjoy it, and if you have a small group of friends this is a great game to spend those hours together. Everything is polished, the graphics, the sound, which has exceptional music. 7.5/10, would be a 9/10 if made easier for singleplayer.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												TLDR at the bottomThis will be my first and a fairly short review that hopefully gets the good points of this game across. This game is awesome. It is an indie game that will test your friendships on the highest level. It plays similar to diablo, with the need for reflexes like you're playing an FPS, and the mindpower for puzzle game. The thing that I found most pleasing in this game is the difficulty.In the past (NES/SNES/Sega) there was no difficulty level, you just dealt with what they gave you. This game can be done the easy way and still have a good time, but if you choose to go the hard route... the game will make you cry. This game is so pleasingly unforgiving and the developers as well. Having met a few I love their mentality towards the game and makes me a happy owner. For the people complaining about the problems. BF4, Skyrim, CoD or any other AAA title that had bugs up the yin yang and still people applauded how amazing it was. Not to say those games aren't good and that the bugs weren't fixed but why is an indie developer somehow excluded from being forgiven when they fix the bugs. -The game is a lot of fun, developers are awesome people with an awesome story, they actively attempt to fix bugs, challenging as heck, SPIRIT BLADES 4 LYFE!

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												This turns out to be a 'puzzle fighting' style game.  Each individual challenge tends to be fairly well crafted with tricks and particular paths that are easier or harder.  Although it has a leveling system, the challenge based experience can leave you feeling stuck, and there is no actual grinding that can be done to unstick you.  Even so, failing the occasional stuck feeling, the game is enjoyable and worth a try.  I have been unable to actually land a multiplayer game (friends played at a different time than I did, and randoms never accept multiplayer requests), so can't really comment on that experience other than to say if you didn't bring your own friends with you, you probably won't be playing this way.Challenging, with interesting mechanics and good overall quality.Give it a try.

I couldn't find out what they did)PositiveYou can swap between the four classes at any point between levels and customize each as you see fitPuzzles have a degree of difficulty (from what I saw, assuming they continued to increase in challenge) that surpasses many other games of a similar "style"Keep in mind that this is only rated on what I saw and that I didn't commit a great deal of time to it. But another thing to remember is that you can determine the quality of a book by reading just the first paragraph.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												The game's not rock solid just yet, and still crashes every so often, but so far version 1.2 has remained stable during a level (which is the most important thing). This is TONES better than 1.1 which crashed randomly all the time.I still have a few issues which prevent me from giving it a stamp of recommended:- As far as I can tell, you can't re-assign buttons on the controller. It would be nice to use a D-pad instead of the sticks.- Still crashes every so often, which isn't a problem in any other games I've played.- So far, I can only get local co-op to work with 1 gamepad, and 1 keyboard+mouse. It would be nice to have both players on game pads.Things are starting out slowly, which I hope pick up soon, with larger areas and more variety in combat. Other than that, so far the game-play is good. There's a good balance for single screen co-op (single screen, wepon loadout, tightly focused levels), and the spirit ball mechanic is a good team-building idea even though at first it seemed like a bit of a gimmic.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												some good stuff:+ some levels make good use of the mechanics (you have a floating ball that goes to the player who presses Space and you use it to light up some beacons) + i like the different abilities each of the 4 character havesome bad stuff:- short- some frustrating levels to complete 100% - requires some precise timing, luck and 4-people coordination, but the server doesn't help it with a high latency (lag).- you get a character but you can easily change it between phases and you start it from scratch, needing to skill up every time (your level is tied to an account, not character) - so no deep conection to characters (that is a con to me) - bad story (although this is quite irrelevant - you dont pick this kind of game for its story)overall: - wouldn't recommend it. It is not very polished and frankly looks like a demo of a bigger game.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												I can't speak to how this game plays in a co-op setting, as of July 2014, there is no one left playing this game anymore - but I can speak to its single-player campaign.This game is simply not fun if you play by yourself.   Everything is balanced for multiple players, after the first couple trials, the game simply becomes tedious if you're trying to do everything on your own.While I appreciate a good challenge, this game focuses on the wrong place.  The puzzles are brain-dead easy, and the single-player challenge simply comes from throwing an ever-increasing amount of mobs at you.   If it was possible to out-run these enemies and kite their numbers down, it would be manageable, but as they all move faster than you and, in many levels, respawn faster than you can kill them it makes the singleplayer game completely unenjoyable.

												Games has poor hit detection and isn't meant for single player. I couldn't even make it through the Hall of Trials 4th section because all the enemies move at least 3x as fast as the character. Also, the game mistakenly assumes that you are playing multiplayer game even though I am standing there alone in single player. It still uses plural forms. Really? You couldn't be bothered to change the text or the audio? I couldn't be bothered to play it again. I was expecting something better than this. Why does the character move so much slower while attacking? Realism? This is a fantasy game! I haven't tried the multiplayer, and I am not sure if I want to after my poor first impressions from the single player. Borderlands also gave me this problem. I regret buying the 4-pack of this game as I don't really want to share it with anyone else.I might change my review if I play it again in the future. For now though, as a single player experience, this game leaves MUCH to be desired. I'm going back to Torchlight II.

Posted: April 21
												I can't comment on the gameplay because I bought this game for local coop and couldn't even start the co-op campaign. It is completely unplayable with two wireless Xbox 360 controllers.Some issues I ran into while trying to play this game:* The first splashscreen just has a text label to "Continue". Pressing a button on the controller causes it to be overlayed with a "NO_BUTTON" text label* Unable to select a two-player co-op with a controller, only 3 or 4. Workaround: select with a mouse* Pressing "A to join" on a second controller causes a player to be addded to the game twice controlling two characters at once. Yes, it's as dumb as it sounds. Workaround: Force 2 player coop (see item 1)* Once a proper two player coop is selected, each player has different controller setup (and they are not configurable). Player 1 has "fire" set to RT, and Player 2 has "fire" set to D-pad right.* I can't enter the settings menu from the main menu using a controller* A lot of pop-ups have placeholder messages for "No translation for language" even though the rest of the game is in EnglishThis is far as I got before I gave up. I sincerely hope that the singleplayer or online coop is amazing, I might try them out one day.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Played with a full 4 players, and while it was fun at first, the puzzle elements quickly became too fiddly and the overall level of difficulty too great.The main puzzle mechanic is that there is a companion character who is basically a glowing ball, which you move around only by calling it to where you are currently standing with a button press; in this way it will only move point to point in straight lines.  Moving the ball over various level objects actives them; you flip switches, move crates, and activate temporary buffs for your character this way.  However the problem is that you have to be quite precise with these movements; the ball is often quite small in relation to the screen and must move exactly over the thing you want to active.  This demands far too much precision in a game where you're often trying to focus on combat at the same time, and dealing with an isometric camera that is frequently zooming out to fit all characters on screen.  If the ball had a larger radius of activation, it would go a long way to making the game more entertaining than frustrating.The level of precision required is the main source of the game's excessive difficulty.  The combat by itself is reasonable, but almost everything after the first set of levels requires managing the ball to solve puzzles while fighting at the same time and the game isn't rewarding enough to make investing the effort feel worth it.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												The bugs in this game are impressive. Between the repeating "Space Space Space" and controller support dropping out until a restart, it's kinda hard to tell which one is my favorite. That's a lie. My favorite bug make progression difficult for some people.... So I started playing this with 2 friends and after a few hours, we went to bed having enjoyed the mechanics that make this game challenging. We were eager to get back into it the next night but I had errands to run. So my friends used the game's built in profile system to create a new profile so they could play fresh without me and switch back when I jumped in. Well, that worked fine until they switched back and their crystal count dropped to zero. Thanks to some complaints on the forum, we solved the problem easy and kept playing till we reached the final(?) boss and lost repeatedly.In case someone else has the same problem, here's a rough explanation of the easy workaround: First, go the data folders on the affected machines for the game and set them to readonly. Then on the master machine(the guy who didn't swap profiles), use HFS webserver to host the master data folder. Then, simply run the following c# code on the effected machines(might need to changes some variables) before you start the game every time. This way, the master machine keeps progressing in the game and the other machines get a copy of that progression before the game starts. Easy as pie!C# code(I ran it in Linqpad):string userFolderName = Directory.GetDirectories(@"C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\userdata\").FirstOrDefault();string mainDir = userFolderName + @"\249990\";string profilePath = mainDir + @"\remote\PROFILE_";string cachedPath = mainDir + @"remotecache.vdf";bool readOnly = (new FileInfo(profilePath)).IsReadOnly;("ReadOnly:"+readOnly).Dump();(new FileInfo(profilePath)).IsReadOnly = false;(new FileInfo(cachedPath)).IsReadOnly = false;var profileSplit = File.ReadAllLines(profilePath)[0].Split('*');string steamId = profileSplit[1];string steamName = profileSplit[2];(steamId + ":" + steamName).Dump();//profileSplit.Dump();var client = new WebClient();client.DownloadFile("http://192.168.0.108/249990/remotecache.vdf",cachedPath+"1");client.DownloadFile("http://192.168.0.108/249990/remote/PROFILE_",profilePath+"1");File.Delete(cachedPath);File.Delete(profilePath);File.Move(cachedPath+"1",cachedPath);File.Move(profilePath+"1",profilePath);var crypt = new System.Security.Cryptography.SHA1CryptoServiceProvider();var allOldBytes = File.ReadAllBytes(profilePath);int oldBytesLength = allOldBytes.Length;var oldSha = String.Join("",crypt.ComputeHash(allOldBytes).Select (x => x.ToString("x2")));(oldBytesLength + ":" + oldSha).Dump();var newProfileSplit = File.ReadAllLines(profilePath)[0].Split('*');string wrongSteamId = newProfileSplit[1];string wrongSteamName = newProfileSplit[2];(wrongSteamId + ":" + wrongSteamName).Dump();string allText = File.ReadAllText(profilePath);string fixedText = allText.Replace(wrongSteamId, steamId).Replace(wrongSteamName, steamName);File.WriteAllText(profilePath, fixedText);var allNewBytes = File.ReadAllBytes(profilePath);int newBytesLength = allNewBytes.Length;var newSha = String.Join("",crypt.ComputeHash(allNewBytes).Select (x => x.ToString("x2")));(newBytesLength + ":" + newSha).Dump();string allCachedText = File.ReadAllText(cachedPath);string fixedCachedText = allCachedText.Replace("\""+oldBytesLength, "\""+newBytesLength).Replace(oldSha, newSha);File.WriteAllText(cachedPath, fixedCachedText);(new FileInfo(profilePath)).IsReadOnly = readOnly;(new FileInfo(cachedPath)).IsReadOnly = readOnly;Jokes aside, it's a fun game but if you hit a rough bug, you might end up rage quitting for good.

number of helpful: 15 of 31 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I had high hopes for this game and was sorely disappointed. The levels are fun and it encourages good teamates. Some abilities are completely worthless but it is well made how each person has a different role to play and is quite different. The problem is based off horrible limiting/restricting design decisions. For no apparent reason, they take the moronic "super meat-boy" approach of screwing you over if you can't beat the level in the exact way they intended you to. The levels are hard enough in themselves and take 5-8 minutes each. You only get new abilities for beating levels, and for beating in in a time limit they choose and by completing a challenge they made up. The first problem is you don't know the challenge till after you beat the level which shows how much they want to artificially inflate game length by having you replay the exact same level multiple times. The time limits and challenges are not even remotely fair or achievable without dozens of attempts of the exact same level, of 6 minutes or so, spending hours on a single level. Why would you not want someone to get to use abilities you made for characters? Biggest problem is that althought you can move through the entire game gaining the crystal for beating the level, the final boss requires a stupid amount of crystals, basically making my entire playthrough a waste of time because I couldn't beat the levels in the exact amount of time developers and tryhards do.........If people like repeatedly playing levels over and over give time limits and challenges that help for leaderboards and rankings, idiots eat that Sh-it up. But don't keep me from getting abilities and from beating the game without letting me know beforehand. Amateur game-making at its finest. Why not have the best of both worlds......it's just ridiculous how a college kid thinks of better game design and implimentation than game developers.....guess the one of the hamsters in the wheels got loose. 5/10

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												I was super-excited when this game came out because I'm always looking for great co-op games to play with one of my friends. We played this for a few hours but eventually abandoned it when we got to a level we couldn't get past.The game does a good job of forcing players to actually cooperate. But we found that when we only had 2-players that the levels became brutally hard. A single death meant all of the enemies homed in on the last man standing. Add in a few levels with insta-death from lazer-like barriers and we reached a level (after only 2 hours; the Slarth boss-fight) where the difficulty ramped up past our skill.A quick check of Steam stats shows that only 19% of players beat Slarth.It stopped being fun, so we moved on to other games. Maybe it is better with 4 players? Or maybe we're just not good enough (but I've played a decent amount of Super Meat Boy so I'm not TERRIBLE). Either way, the frustration exceeded the fun for us.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												FORCED: A game to improve your relationship with your significant other.Ever get that feeling that your communication is lacking with your significant other?  You just wish there was a better way to work out *how* to talk to each other, and really be heard.  Well, here is the answer!  FORCED!  There is nothing to improve a relationship like coordinating where to pass a flaming ball of doom, who should focus fire on the boss and who should be on adds, or call out for your partner's help when you are getting overrun and have them valiantly come to your rescue.  This game *forces* you to work with your partner, to be aware of them at all times, and to understand that the survival of all parties involved is not only important, but practically integral to the success of many levels.  You will die.  You will die again, and again, and again.  There will be chronic confusion of who Balfus should be following.  There might be an unsavory word uttered under someone's breath here and there.  There might even be a declaration of, "This isn't worth it, I quit."  To which you will respond, "We *can* do it!"  It will be a rollercoaster of trials, testing your patience and your sanity, but once victory is achieved it provides an addictive feeling of fulfillment that pushes you, no, *forces* you forward.  You will find yourself strategizing, trying different techniques, characters and relying on your reflexes to get you through the truly chaotic portions.  You will share your frustrations with your partner, but you will also rejoice together.  One precisely placed heal will mean the difference between life and death for your partner, or that perfectly timed shout out for Balfus to be passed through a totem determining the victory of the level.  You will fall asleep with images of FORCED running through your mind, working out newly improved strategies for your next session.You will then inevitably understand that the most important rule of FORCED, and of relationships, is:United you will stand, divided you will fall.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Introduction:The Story behind this game is about a town of humans who spend their lives training and work for the God. Throughout the year they send warriors from their village to go deep into the realms to battle the guardians and try to defeat them, but none prevailed. After a long await four warriors came forth from the villages and started to slay the Guardians as one god tries to guide them through the realms or chaos. As the Warriors it's your destiny to send them to the right path.Graphics:Throughout the game the graphics for this game have been great quality and had had some amazing sceneries, not a lot is need to play this game and with a lot more room for improvement I wouldn't put any bad remarks towards this game just yet, with the design and the equipment, to the boss and bad guys. The game shows the player it can be like WoW and Rift, full of imagination and fantastic detail in the structuresGame play:The game play in this game was very easy to understand, with the first few levels explain how certain objects word, the game challenges you through the levels, making sure you are fully aware of what certain things do and how to stop them. The game is based on a third person play and you can roam around the game with either a keyboard and mouse or a Controller.  for those who are PC gamers keyboard and mouse was easier for the bow master, but I personally liked the controller because of close combat so try and find something that'll suit your style. I play Volcanic Hammer and controller was my thing, but when it came to bow I had to switch. The detail in the inventory and explanation were simple and this is what a game need as for beginner people feel comfortable knowing what's going on throughout the start and not be pressured and button mash. Each character has different abilities and fighting styles, if you read the spoiler then you understand what I mean. But try and find the right warrior for you and play with him till you get used to his abilities and powers.Advantages:This is one of the funniest Coop RPG games I played, with me and my mates we flied through the levels and got more excited as the game went on, the boss and ideas that were put into the puzzles were genius, as well as hard. this game is good at both Single player and Coop. with coop play the game is at its best, you can roam and fight and work together to counter every possible bad guys and boss, but they also help you with strategies as all weapons will be in your arsenal so go and find the best ways to different each level.Disadvantages:As much as I love this game, there are a few bugs and downers on this game, one of them is the servers, through the game it won’t let you access other servers or game plays when you play coop, also when you host a game is sometimes freezes the game and closes the game down, making you restart from your last checkpoint, luckily this doesn't erase you data and you keep all you equipment, but this will frustrate you big time, even if your near completion or in the middle of a boss battle.Overall:I believe that even though this game has a lot of problems with it, I'm going to give it faith and say it's still a great game, the Developer is personally speaking to me and with anyone else who is in trouble and will help you throughout the game. For now I will give this game a 6/10 due to the bugs, but I recommend this game in the future.  With the designers fixing every problem and working hard on the patches this game will be a major success in the future. So don't get dishearted just yet. With the future patches I believe this game can hit 9.5/10 in my books as long as the serves get fixed and the game play continues.Thanks you for reading and peace out :)

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Forced is a multiplayer heavy game. i really dont recommend playing alone, as it is not as much fun and also some of the challanges are very hard or even impossible without other people helping you control the orb/ fight the mobs.it would also be pretty cool to see each class have their own "combo" with each other that can change your playstyle if you change class instead of just holding the attack button and use your skill when enemies are fully marked (marks is a system where if you hit the enemies they will get mark, more marks=more damage to skills)gameplay is basically a multiplayer coop puzzle action rpg game, where gems act as "levels" , more gems you have means more skills/shortcuts are unlocked for your character. i dont really like the only 3 shortcuts at max, but maybe this is so the game wouldnt be too easy, as the skills dont have that long cool down.my favourite part is probably the bossest. each have their own way to kill and each works differently, you may need to swap a few classes to see which is most efficient for which boss. graphics are pretty good, not in a high res way, but it looks pretty unique in the enemy/your character design, though i wish there is more customization done for your character other than picking out which skill to use.fun game, even more with friends. get it if you have friends to play, if not then they do have lobbies for that but it seems like the servers have wobbly connectiong or net code because it connects whenever it feels like, only when its a private game your friend or you make will work. at least, thats what happened to me. this will probably get fixed soon.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												I was really expecting something good out of this title, with all the positive steam reviews and the promise of a fun puzzle-y RPG-y Co-op experience. What I got was a poorly optimized game with iOS game-style level design and netcode issues. One of the primary mechanics in the game is this orb which each player can call to their location. It seems all puzzles, if you can even call them that, are based on this mechanic. The problem here is that these puzzles are all really uninventive and quite frankly boring, and using the orb for all puzzles doesn't make for a rewarding and interesting experience. The level design reminds me of iOS games because of its infatuation of having really short, play-while-you're-on-the-toilet missions which give you a ranking between 1 and 3 depending on how well you did. One for completing the level, one for doing some special thing, and one for doing it quickly. I really think this is a horrible practice for PC games and I was hoping for some Diablo-style adventuring which would fit the game a lot better than how it is now.These problems combined with the shoddy netcode (this was playing with 3 others with pings varying between 10-30ms) lead to a really unresponsive and disapointingly mediocre experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Forced is like some insane mashup of an action RPG and basketball. The central mechanic of using a spirit-ball that much be passed around between players and used to activate, destroy or otherwise do anything important is an excellent co-op mechanic that's a ton of fun.On the flip side, however, network play can be quite buggy, our party had several challenges fail to reset properly, issues connecting to hosts, and even a couple instances of two players being assigned to control of the same avatar.These issues will hopefully be solved in future patches and the good news is that once you get the game running with everyone connected, it generally works quite well.If you don't mind dealing with a few network bugs and have some friends to play with, Forced is an interesting and challenging co-op experience that isn't like anything else you're likely to have played.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Not gonna lie, the single player isn't all that great, but it really isn't made to be a single player game. Hook your rig up to a TV, get some controlers set up, and invite a few friends over and you'll be in for an absolute blast with this game. It's been half a decade since I've had this much fun playing a game with a group of friends. There are many games that have you playing in the same virtual space but not really playing it together. This game's ingenious design facilitates working together with the core mechanics without feeling like gimmicks. Call your friends over, you must play this game.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												This game is a puzzle co-operative game, you can play it single player or coop. The graphics are good, the performance is good, there isn't any stuttering, there aren't freezes. There aren't an excessive amount of controls to get used to, this game compared to other coop games like magicka has better coop synergy, partially because of its puzzle based nature. You can move and fire your bow which is a positive aspect about this game, I appreciated this because i've played Alien Swarm and i like the movement controls. There's an ability to switch between controller and keyboard and mouse and the support for controller is great. The negative aspects of this game is that people can't join while your playing, if they do then you have to restart your game if you want them to play, you can't make private matches, if someone leaves the game then you are taken back to multiplayer screen. I don't find any technical problems with this game.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Unless you like the party game dungeon crawl genre, I'd suggest skipping this, or waiting until it's fully finished. The glitches in the current version make it nearly unplayable.Me and three friends tried playing a few games together - all of us had issues at different intervals using/equipping new skills, which then doesn't allow movement onto the next stage. Start over a new game.Second try we experienced the same issue with different players. Third try I became de-synched during a match so the best I could do was attempt to keep up while my character slowly glitched around, lagging behind the party who were still fully functioning. I'd have to say this caused more unintended hilarity and fun in the game than when the game was running smoothly.Toss in a few random crashes, and we haven't really bothered playing this since.With a bit of polish it might be fun, and the graphics are "ok" but not awe inspiring or even surprising. The level design is fairly straight forward, and the puzzles were decently challenging while intuitive, rather than being frustratingly obtuse, which is a good plus.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Ok, here is a review which shouldn't be written by me as I don't have the play time to make a fair judgement, but it seems no-one else has discussed this.5 words? FORCED. Seems good, no weight.Okay, now for the lengthy bit.... What do you mean by 'no weight'? well, that's pretty straight forward really, every strike, stab, stomp and shot you perform has no impression of impact in the sound or visual effects, it doesn't feel like you are striking down someone to the pits of the earth, it feels like you are pushing them over so they gentle fall onto a bed.Now, while this may make sense for the assassin-type character, this should not be the case with the warrior wielding a freaking HUGE FLAMING AXE.Don't get me wrong, the art-style is nice, the puzzles are cool, the soundtrack would be nice if you didn't have to choose between silence or being deafened and perhaps that's also the reason the fighting sucks, you have to turn the game sounds so far down in order to be able to hear your friends that you miss out on any subtle sounds such as impacts and also miss out on the soundtrack. The guide however? Oh, he'll violate your ear-drums silly if you don't shut him up quickly.Overall, FORCED probably isn't that bad, but it just wasn't mine or my friends' cup of tea. It was just boring, and trust me, I really wanted to enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												When I first got this game it was plagued with all sorts of issues. The main issue that I had was that while playing a game hosted locally it would claim that I lost connection. If you check out the reviews from earlier in the games life there are plenty of other networking issues that arose, along with other bugs. Fortunately the team that developed this game has been on top of it releasing patch after patch. At this point the game is a great hack'n'slash puzzler. Basically Gauntlet with less killing and more complicated puzzle levels. The class and leveling system are a lot of fun and Balfus, your mentor and spirit guide, is a lot of fun. I only play local co-op so I can't speak for the online co-op but I did notice that the game list is usually fairly sparce, but if you have a few friends this is a great game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												As a someone who codes for a living and earned a degree in game design there are a few expectations I have. The biggest is a working program. I can overlook bugs, I can overlook the occassional crash. What I cannot do is spend hours trying to get something to work. This game seemed right up my alley considering I have very little time to game; relatively quick levels, freedom to revisit levels, and fairly simple controls (good for when I go weeks without being able to game.)The problem I'm encountering is constant crashing, every time I played the game it crashed during a fight. Out of the 100+ games I have on Steam this and Dungeon Defenders don't work. Dungeon Defenders is an issue with my setup and I haven't had time to try the recommended fixes. Unfortunately this game doesn't even give me any clue as to why it crashes. It just freezes and can't be stopped through task manager because it stays as the fore window.Although this cost next to nothing (on sale) I would still like something that doesn't require me to jump through a ton of hoops in order to get back to a working system.Good effort and probably a great game, but I will never know because my time is more valuable than the reward of playing a game that has nothing truly unique.

												So, my friend and I were in a trial. We had to avoid grinders majority of the way. We come across two grinders side by side with only a straight corridor to lead us. Him and I both assume that we must outrun them. Wrong. As soon as we stand on the platform to start the sequence, we both dash out in both directions, getting pulverized instantly because the grinders were going to be so much faster than we thought. Turns out we just had to be patient and await the proper opportunity to not get turned into cube-steak. This game is truly challenging, always keeps you guessing, and really ♥♥♥♥s you up. But I love it. Hands down- 10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												This hack n' slash game will keep you on your toes, as it contains skill-based combat and puzzles that require you think on your feet.  It doesn't bother with the story and instead opts to focus entirely on the gameplay, which is fortunate because it is well thought-out.  Something of special note is that it is designed with co-op in mind, but while some games don't do any balancing, this game does ALL the balancing.  You have completely unique puzzles for anywhere from 1 to 4 players, and frequently puzzles will require all members of a team.It has challenges for each stage (beat it in X time, etc), but they are absurdly difficult, so I recommend you play through the story, then that's it.  Get it on a sale.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												This game would be fun if it didn't have the mechanic of guiding a glowing ball around, while you're trying to fight off enemies. The combat is just fine, but you also have to solve puzzles and have way quicker reflexes than the casual gamer to simultaneously light torches/blow stuff up/snuff out mists. To me, it falls into the same category as Magicka, wherein it combines too much stuff into one game for it to be fun. But maybe I'm just getting crotchety and old and prefer my Gauntlet-esque games to be more like Gauntlet.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I bought a three-pack of FORCED to play with some friends and it is literally one of the worst games we've ever played. It feels like an high resolution Nintendo 64 title. Its gameplay is shallow and its graphics are ugly. There is no story to speak of. The voice acting is atrocious. It plays like a Mario Kart battle match or 1-on-1 Halo fight but without the fun of either of those games. The most I can say for FORCED is that we did not experience connection issues or other major during the <1 hour we wasted on this shallow, unfun game.

Posted: June 15, 2014
												Not a bad game. It is lacking in the RPG department though, no leveling up at all or skill points. You basically beat challenges and earn crystals, depending how many crystals you have unlocked will depend on what skills you can choose. This is a very "mobile game" type of mechanic if you ask me. So while it works ok I just feel the game is lacking in the RPG department.Essentially it is an Action game with skill unlocks minus RPG elements like leveling and skill points.Again not a bad game but I was slightly disappointed in the lack of leveling and skill points and so on.The story line is nothing to write home about either.The game does have some light puzzle elements but nothing too bad.Honestly there are better games out there, but this game is ok.Co-op would probably be the best way to play this so if you are getting it for co-op then I would definitley recommend it.I would give the game a 6.5/10.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Well constructed game. Spectacular graphics, and a cool view of your puzzle/arena as you simultaneously handle cool opponents and solve interesting puzzles, all with the side commentary (often entertaining) from a magical floating ball you control, the arena god named Balfus. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												If I'm to classify Forced as anything, it's a cooperative MOPA - Multiplayer Online Puzzler Arena ;)Really good co-op game, with both fun and challenging combat system and clever but not too convoluted action-oriented puzzles, both rewarding you greatly for good teamwork and communication. Since each mission is its own little arena it's easy to pick up and play for a little while with people joining and leaving as they like, although I'd encourage you to play with friends to get the most (screaming and fighting over the shiny ball) out of it! ^^ Each class is tied to weapons and you "level" all the classes at the same time. Classes are divided between players so you can't play the same thing, which also encourages teamwork and letting the best suited for different tasks do their thing, but you can also switch classes freely between each mission. Since you can also skip some missions, it means you can decide difficulty by avoiding harder ones if you really want to, but I for one found the difficulty on an appropriate level. As far as co-op games goes this one is nearly perfect. The controls feels sharp and responsive, and the skills fairly intuitive. You can fight a boss without taking damage by timing dodges perfectly, or you can die miserably by doing it poorly. There's a nice balance between individual skill and teamwork that you usually (hopefully) find in MOBAs like LoL and DotA, but to me what it reminds me most of is running dungeons in WoW, minus the gear frenzy and hunter pets pulling all the mobs. Overall, I strongly recommend Forced, especially in four-packs.Trying to think of anything bad... we've had occasional random lag/framedrops for no apparent reason, but not a lot. There used to be some crippling network issues that appear to have been resolved. It seems some of the missions are in fact impossible to solo, but since you can skip some levels that may be possible to go around, I haven't tried. Although I have to say you kinda miss out on the point if you play it alone.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Not a bad game. It is lacking in the RPG department though, no leveling up at all or skill points. You basically beat challenges and earn crystals, depending how many crystals you have unlocked will depend on what skills you can choose. This is a very "mobile game" type of mechanic if you ask me. So while it works ok I just feel the game is lacking in the RPG department.Essentially it is an Action game with skill unlocks minus RPG elements like leveling and skill points.Again not a bad game but I was slightly disappointed in the lack of leveling and skill points and so on.The story line is nothing to write home about either.The game does have some light puzzle elements but nothing too bad.Honestly there are better games out there, but this game is ok.Co-op would probably be the best way to play this so if you are getting it for co-op then I would definitley recommend it.I would give the game a 6.5/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26
												Frustratingly fun, despite some issues with massive lag with enemy swarms. Keep on top of the spawners, guys. It's probably one of the most fun experiences I've had playing a co-op game, though. You need to know how the enemies attack to dodge properly, and to keep an eye on everything going on so that spawners or smoke doesn't get out of hand. This makes it so the game isn't so easy as to be boring, but it's also not so difficult as to be impossible. You do need to communicate with the people you're playing with, though, especially in later levels. If you run around like independent agents you'll most likely sabotage the whole team. It's a little annoying when playing the game with someone with fewer crystals than you, since everyone adjusts to the person with the fewest. You won't be able to play any later levels or use abilities they don't have access to yet, no matter how much you love those abilities, though I can see why it's like that. Having higher level abilities on earlier challenges might make them too easy, and this isn't a game that wants to be easy.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												I picked this up soon after buying and play Gauntlet. It was on sale for like 6 bucks and it seemed like a pretty similar game. In my opinion, this game blows Gauntlet out of the water. All four classes were awesome, with scaling move trees to customize your ability setup. Really fun co op game and extremely challenging single player game. I completed the entire game and got all but 2 achievements in single player mode. The only game to be as difficult to complete by myself to date is Bloodborne. But it was worth it, amazing game and I'm hopeful for more content or even a sequel.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												I was blown away by FORCED. In a world where we've come to accept that Indie developers rely on Early Access and AAA developers lean on pre-orders and DLC it's refreshing to see a game made by a small independent studio that delivers.The graphics, gameplay mechanics, and puzzles are all great quality. I've had lots of fun with this game and it's worth every penny.There are a couple of cons though and that would be that you pretty much need to play with other people. While playing solo is very much possible is it much more difficult. I know they've tried to address this by allowing single-player respawning and that has helped.Secondly when I played there were some network issues when I played with certain friends, which I guess came down to network settings, etc. I think they have in the mean-time fixed most of these issues as well.Overall, it's a great game to play during a LAN party or with some friends over voice.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												+ Great concept of a fast action hack'n'slash with added "puzzles" which are not actually puzzles, more like triggers needed to complete each level+ Nice looking graphics reminiscent of Torchlight, Deathspank and others+ 4 Unique classes with interesting skills+ Unique skill gem system that encourages level replayability, but can be frustrating at times (see below)+ Developers involved in the community and responding extremely fast to any reported issues+ Great sounding music and almost perfect voice acting with a few minor hiccups here and there- No difficulty setting (overall game difficulty is Medium-Hard with a few Hardcore levels)- Frustratingly difficult levels mixed with stupidly easy ones.- Luck can make or break a game, skill rarely comes into effect- Unbalanced classes, found myself playing the shield wielder more than any other class- Mostly impossible to complete level challenges for casual players, some levels require as much as 50 runs to get all the gems, the timed ones are really a pain to complete, better stick a fork in your eye than attempt them- Broken co-op multiplayer, connection to other player's "servers" works 2/10, there is no option to configure the server at all. There isn't even an explanation about it, I still don't know if the gem numbers on servers represent the required number to join or just an indication to the host's "level"It's hard to give this game a note because there isn't something to compare it too. I think it can be polished some more and it sure needs the difficulty to be decreased for more casual players. Right now it feels like you are taking part in a championship or tournament that has no prize at the end making all the frustrating experience to go through all of it pointless.Maybe some extra levels at the end or a fifth class to be unlocked could have made it more interesting, especially to encourage co-op replayability.I will give it a 7/10 though especially for the idea, effort and team commitment.

content:
Posted: March 26
												Frustratingly fun, despite some issues with massive lag with enemy swarms. Keep on top of the spawners, guys. It's probably one of the most fun experiences I've had playing a co-op game, though. You need to know how the enemies attack to dodge properly, and to keep an eye on everything going on so that spawners or smoke doesn't get out of hand. This makes it so the game isn't so easy as to be boring, but it's also not so difficult as to be impossible. You do need to communicate with the people you're playing with, though, especially in later levels. If you run around like independent agents you'll most likely sabotage the whole team. It's a little annoying when playing the game with someone with fewer crystals than you, since everyone adjusts to the person with the fewest. You won't be able to play any later levels or use abilities they don't have access to yet, no matter how much you love those abilities, though I can see why it's like that. Having higher level abilities on earlier challenges might make them too easy, and this isn't a game that wants to be easy.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												As much as I might like the idea of this type of game, this is not how it should be done. Only positive is the game mechanics that really forces you to coop. But other than that there are many things like :1. Horrible, horrible gamepad/keyboard support, it just switches randomly, we have to restart games all the time because during loading the game decides to ignore my controller2. Horrible stability. Lags, disconnects, twitching, stuttering. Game is nowhere near complex or pretty enough to lagg on my beast of a machine.3. UI and lack of options. There are just too many things wrong with the UI, the way you setup things, game needs more solid visual identifiers, especially during the hectic missions.4. Polish. This game badly needs one. So many bugs, from visual ones where you can't even see because of the "SPACE SPACE SPACE" all over the screen, to glitches and teleports.5. Lack of skill variety. It might seem that there is a ton of skills, but many are just plain bad, plus many are about creating marks on enemies, with very little skills to remove them often enough.TLDR -> If you want a 4man coop top down twin stick brawler, buy and play Gauntlet, that's a solid example of a polished, smooth game.
