content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I really hate having to recommend against getting this game. I really wanted to like it but the experience the game gave just declined over the course of 14 hours. Let's start from the beginning.I bought this game pretty much right after it came out in 2013 and played it with 2 other friends. The net-code was unstable at launch which made it extremely difficult to get online co-op games (one of the main selling points) to work. When it did work though it was great entertainment. However, an unstable multiplayer was not the only mechanical issue I ran into and I crashed several times. Add numerous bugs and you have a less than stellar experience. A year later I picked up the game to finish it and while the net-code has gotten better it's still wonky and there are still bugs throughout, in fact the last boss fight of the game was more or less ruined as the big bad evil guy crapped out on me and was stuck in his walking cycle unnable to attack.Even with those mechanical flaws I still managed to have a good time but at the halfway mark of the game things just go down hill. See the game is structured a lot like an old Crash Bandicoot game (the second one to be exact). The game is split into worlds that has a series of levels along with a boss fight. Every level has 3 crystals to obtain. The first is obtained by simply beating the level, the second by completing a challenge tied to the level and finally a crystal based on completion time.The structure works really well and here's why: The game is a mix of RPG, Hack 'N' Slash and light Puzzle elements. Your character has active abilities, passive abilities and a special ability tied to each of the 4 classes (Hammer charges over time, bow can be charged manually, shield blocks etc.). However, in order gain new abilities you need to get crystals by beating levels. This creates a very real incentive to complete levels several times to pick up all the crystals.This brings us to the levels themselves and the puzzle element. Throughout the game you'll be escorted by Balfus a flying orb that might as well have been called Navi. Balfus has a lot of quips throughout the game and he happily chats away whenever he's given the chance and becomes real grating, real fast. Especially when constantly replaying levels to get those final crystals. Now the levels are structured so that you need Balfus to activate several items and objects by making him fly into them and for the first half of the game it's great fun to play with all the different objects in the world and there are some really creative puzzles in there. Like I said though, at the half way point it seriously starts to feel like you're simply going through the motions and things become repetitive just like Balfus' endlessly repeating lines.Another few gripes I feel deserve mentioning are the bosses whom have way to much health for their own good, seriously they are ♥♥♥♥ing sponges soaking damage like high-end kleenexes. The mark system which adds extra damage from abilities and basic attacks don't do enough to quickly wear down bosses at a reasonable rate and the boss levels which are supposed to be epic become tedious. The fact that the invisible creatures can only be spotted by Balfus and the fact there's only one Balfus and most likely more than one player it is aggrivating to kill just one, especially when they have enough health to soak several fully marked abilities. I could go on but I think I've made my point.In conclusion, I feel really bad for not recommending the game because I know this is the first game by the dev team and I know they worked really hard on it, but it just lacks polish and the player-experience is not optimal as a result. If you really want to play this game, get it on sale.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												If you want a good coop game then look elsewhere!Where to start? Want deep character customization? Too bad! Pick between four set characters (if a buddy grabs your favorite character, you have to play as a different one) with only one weapon set per character. while you can certainly upgrade their abilities and switch between a few special powers per character, its hardly in depth enough to make you feel like you have the ability to make important changes to your character to augment to your own playing style. And with zero loot in the game you aren't allowed to even optimize your character's gear in any way.Howabout the maps? Well, don't play this game expecting long sprawling dungeons, each level is more of a small arena with waves of enemies and little puzzles to solve. And when I mean arena I literally mean a smallish circular map where enemies will run in from doorways on the outside as well as from a few spawners. Its been extremely difficult to connect with friends, but when working the teamwork required to get through these levels is simple, but enjoyable enough (though it is a simple button masher) when played in coop, however that leads me to the greatest problem of this game in my opinion:When playing coop with friends with each of you on DIFFERENT computers, you are still forced to share the camera as if playing a couch coop with your buddies on the same screen. This can lead to anything from mild annoyance to intense frustration while playing. I can think of nothing more frustrating while trying to play this game then when my character is pushed off the screen because my friends are on the other side of the screen, and I am now forced to fight blindly or ask my friends to stop what they're doing and come back to my side of the arena. This problem might not be as frustrating when played with just 1-2 other friends, but if you get a full group of four together you'll run into this problem often. Its possible this has been fixed, though the fact that you were ever forced (no pun intended) to play this way in the first place is ridiculous!In terms of replayability, there is no randomness to this game, or any abundance of places you might of missed to explore. The game's main sense of replayability comes in the fact that each arena playthrough is timed, and ranked among others. The incentive being to replay the arena to try and get a better score.There's a reason why most of the people reviewing this game don't make it past twenty hours of game time... However, that being said, if this sounds like the type of game you want to play then by all means give it a whirl. Just don't be fooled into thinking that this game will be at all like an in depth rpg dungeon crawler. If you're looking for that type of game look elsewhere.

												The camera for multiplayer in this game is horribly broken. When the players are further apart than half a screen, your view gets offset and zoomed out to keep all players onscreen. That is another very poor design choice.My last gripe is that I don't feel like the game has much replayability. Once I complete a very difficult task and get the extra gem, I don't want to do it ever again. That isn't a desireable feature for any game.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												This game reminded me of Gauntlet, so my 3 friends and I got it one night and decided to attempt to record it for my YouTube. The sad truth is the game is such garbage that I had 3 corrupted video files before I stopped trying.Between the 4 of us, my friends and I have between medium and advanced gaming rigs... mine being the best. All four of us had repeated game crashes every time we tabbed out of the game, for me it was to start/stop Audacity and for them it was either accident or to check their Twitch streams. However if that was the only issue it wouldn't be too bad, the major issue is this crash in the ended up causing all of our computers to crash and need to be manually restarted. After the 3rd try I stopped tabbing out and decided to run everything before opening the gamem which worked until one of my friends accidentally hit "Main Menu". When he did this, it kicked the 3 remaining players out of the game, crashed the game, and forced a manual restart.Lastly, the least minor thing but during our play none of us could use the controller even though it was an option. The controller settingers were optimized however every time one of us selected the controller it wouldn't allow that person to "ready-up" until they went back to the keyboard. Why even make something an option if your game won't allow you to use it?This game honestly isn't worth your time. We were the only people to have a room in the lobby and that was on a Saturday night, so theres little to no chance of finding a game unless you're solo or your friends were dumb enough to buy this game with you. Sadly, my friends and I attempted to play this game for over 2 hours and I fear we wont get our money back.Rating: 2/10 - Only because they suckered me into buying the deluxe so I can look like more of a bada$$ than my friends.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												A fun game for both playing solo and with friends.  While I've not had any issues with the game other than some graphical glitches, it's been nice to see the developers actively improving the game (better multiplayer connections, better controller support, other bug fixes, and several tweaks to solo play).It's an action RPG in the same genre as Diablo, Torchlight, etc., but with several twists.  It's much more puzzle based, but combat is still an integral part.  Classes are based on the 4 available weapons, and switching classes can be done with no penalty between levels.  Skills are unlocked by completing levels and challenges (one time and one other per level) to get crystals, which unlock abilities at certain numbers and is not tied to a class.  There's no gear progression, so there's no grinding.  In multiplayer, everyone has to have a crystal for it to be available for that play session, so everyone is on an equal footing.I picked this up because it was compatible with Macs, and I've really enjoyed it.  I've played with 1, 2, 3, and 4 players, tried all 4 classes and have 72/75 crystals.Some levels/challenges are significantly easier for either solo or multiplayer (time challenges tend to be more relaxed in multiplayer, but other challenges that require no one screwing up is much easier solo).  Also, the archer seems to be much more powerful compared to the other classes in solo because it is the only class with a ranged basic attack.  Furthermore, once you have 75/75 crystals, I feel there's currently limited replay value, even if you choose a different class.  However, there's a promise for more "endgame" content beyond the current survival mode.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This game, for the low price of $7.49 that I picked up during the winter sales has proven to be worth every cent. The challenges that my friends and I faced has caused us the necessary frustration but the possibility of completing it has kept us at it. We are 70% past the game and honestly, my only wish were that it could be longer as we do love the game. The upside are the stages which are initially simple but you can opt to do the challenges which are much harder and have forced our team to use special set-ups in our attempt to conquer them. A fond way to think of it would be like a 10-25 man dungeon raid you would experience in some of the MMO's but that your team was reduced to 4, including you. Although you can play it single player, it is a much better game to play with friends and I would say your enjoyment rises exponentially with each friend you play with. The downside is that the game is relatively short, if you play without the challenges, you can easily complete in maximum of 1-2 days?This is one of the most challenging games and its still worth every cent.

												Even though the game doesn't play too well for a single player, the true power is in the co-op. If you feel like you're up for a challenge with three of your friends or even more challenging, three strangers, this game is for you. There are some small glitches and problems you may run into while playing online, but thankfully, it's never game-breaking. I would suggest this game for anyone who likes having a good multiplayer experience, especially since every character in the game has a completely different moveset. Try it out and have some fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												FORCED is an interesting game, to say the least. I played it heavily during the initial development, before it was on Steam.The game is a mixture of time trials and Diablo-esque co-op combat, this means you have a persistant character that you level up in either singleplayer, or co-operative levels. These levels involve combat, as well as puzzle solving mechanics where players move and place floating orbs over certain objects for a variety of effects.If you enjoy time challanges, Diablo, or are looking for a co-op game with friends you will be hard pressed to find a better value than FORCED at the current time!You can see my other opinions on the game here:


YouTube™ Video: FORCED First Impressions - FORCED Live Gameplay 

			Views: 172		

			Interested in partnering with VISO? Send me a YouTube message! 10,000+ Views per month required. HEY LOOK, I HAVE SHIRTS AND STUFF!

content:

												This is a puzzle game with a really bad twin stick beat-em up mechanic. No checkpoints in levels. A Twin Stick with no dodge roll, or block button. The twin stick is unnecessary and adds nothing but to make the game harder since it’s hard to see where you are facing. The game is unnecessarily hard and you can get surrounded by enemies and die easily. It's designed to be four players and the same amount of enemies will spawn regardless if it’s just two players or four. There is no way to complete all the challenges single player.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I got to a trial, like #8 or whatever, that was seemingly impossible without a co op partner. Good luck finding anyone else who wants to play this game besides yourself though. It is a below average game at best, based primarily around puzzle solving with really bad generic boring combat. It is best forgotten to games of a much better quality, mainly games that have a single player campaign that doesn't require co op assistance, or at least isn't so incredibly frustrating that it is a complete turn off. This game is very easily forgotten in a sea of other, much more awesome games. It would be a lot better if the combat didn't suck so much and was less frustrating on some challenges that are clearly easier with a partner which you won't find unless you ask strangers in the forums maybe. Oh and did I mention the combat is generic and boring and takes a back seat to puzzle solving? Just making sure I made that clear.

												When the game initially came out, its best co-op of the year award was warranted. However, when trying to play the game now, the non-hosting player will experience lag. content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												Played this with my brother and it was such a blast. We did get stuck in 1 trial for 1 hour but damn! I love the feeling when we surpassed it. That being said. This is a twin stick coop game that needs good communication and patience. It's crucial to have good planning and strategy as well as alertness and quick thinking. If you are a fan of local coop then I highly recommend getting this game. It has an adequate amount of puzzle, action, and challenging enemies to keep you busy. And prepare to shout a lot.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												(At the moment I wouldnt be recommending this game to people I know.)Whilst the concept of this game is very good, combining the elements of an arena fighting game with puzzle mechanics. Myself and my friends have become gradually annoyed many times with little problems that arise from the strange lag, collision detection, clunky camera and online getting the game to linkup.Problems that arose during play- Sometimes found the Spirit orb wouldnt hit shrines or objects when it appeared that it passed directly into them.- When players were spreadout the camera wouldnt help you out.- We had some lag issues between players from UK and Sweden. (no problems in other games)-The online lobby had a few hiccups when setting up the match. (not seeing when Ready)Somethings id love to see added/fixed/updating- rolling or sprint. (due to the fact that everytime I tried to move away from enemies they would keep up and hit me this may or may not have been due to lag (unsure)- individual cameras for players with a button for map view to see other players.- fixing cutscenes and specific little issues with the game."If this is slightly better i would hate to see what the original was like"Cheers Jezereth.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												I don't even know why I bought this game, maybe it was shiny, who knows. What I do know is this game is unfinished. I honestly thought this was just an early access title like many of the others, but no it's not. I checked the store page 3 times to make sure. This game has terrible audio mixing that makes most combat and music either too soft or not audible at all. The sounds are extremely far away if you are using headphones. Voice acting was bad, kinda the reason I wrote that first review after playing the starting trials. This game is just one gauntlet of completionist challenges. Honestly this is battle block theater if you take the platforming away and made it too serious. Really the most laughable part is that they included a built-in twitch streaming platform. In a game that is so boring and requires co-op to be any fun, why do they need to include this? The game is the same ball puzzle, as far as I've played. Use your floating ball to activate shrines and destroy arbitrary spawners and statues.You play the same character as everyone else just in different armor. I say charater but your just a gladiator without a name or face that wears different armor depending on what the lobby leader ♥♥♥♥♥es at you to be. It's a nice feature that you can change classes at whim so there's no commitment to a certain role. With the human husk of a character the story is terrible and the meat of the game is left to repetitive arenas one after the other. Meh, the game's just boring, noticibly unpolished, and requires multiplayer for fun. Also multiplayer is buggy and won't connect at times. So what can you do, play a better game at least.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												I have to congratulate this game for doing something no other piece of software ever managed to do. It manages to shut down both my monitors for 10 minutes of inactivity (at least that's my best guess, maybe it just lulls my graphics card to sleep after a little while), even though I was playing the game for those 10 minutes, which means moving the mouse around and using the keyboard. What's even more impressive is that the same happens whether I play in full screen or windowed mode. And the most impressive thing of all... this means that I can not tab out of the game leaving hard reset button on my case as the only possible way out.In a way this is actually quite a beautiful accomplishment and I could just simply turn off that setting on my PC when I play this game and see if that would help. Or I could also just uninstall this and move on with my life... which I ultimately decided is a healthier option.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Bought it on sale for $2. Its an alright puzzle game, but nothing particularly compelling. Definitely not worth the $14.99 sticker price. Pros: Different weapon sets are useful for different levels, decent co-op play. Low cost on sale. Bosses you beat become toned down normal enemies in following levels, which introduces some neat mechanics in mundane combat. cons: Almost no replayability. Progression requires you to beat levels under a timer and while adhering to generally more difficult challenges, so look forward to playing all of them several times as you go through the story. Low variety of enemies. You'll see the same ones every single level. Puzzles are highly simplistic. Out of 20 story levels only a handful aren't painfully obvious. About half of challenges are super easy to get and you'll end up reaching them just by playing the level, the rest are frustrating and include a strong element of luck requiring you to replay the level multiple times. Stunlock for days. Not all classes have invincibility frames, and several enemy types can pin you against the wall or dogpile you and stunlock you to death. The completely invisible enemies that attack from invis without breaking it only add to this, as they make some attacks legitimately unavoidable. Camera is terribad. It has a maximum zoom and a fixed angle, combined with all the knockbacks its not unsual to have people stuck offscreen. Almost no multiplayer scene: less than five games at a time, coming off of an 85% off sale. Unless you've got friends who own it or buy a fourpack look forward to going it alone.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												This is a challenging game, more because if you don't have a team some things seem impossible.The game works in a way where you level up by gathering crystals which you get from: Finishing a level, Finishing it within a certain amount of time, or doing a challenge in the level. Recently they have added so you can get up to 12 more crystals from Survival modes, but it's not as helpful late game as it is doing it as early as possible.As you level up you gain Perks, Abilities, or a spot for a new one.However, the later it gets the more crystals you will need to get new things, easily trapping you with whatever you have and hoping that you can beat the next level.What I don't like is that even if you play the same level 50 times, you will not get anything from it, especially if you're stuck on it and you can't do any other time/challenge things.I'm still not sure if I recommend this game, it's really frustaring when you stand there with no ways to get the next unlock, but you're also stuck and can't continue.In the end, I will not recommend the game, for the way it treats unlocks, and singleplayer is nearly unable to do if you're an achivement ♥♥♥♥♥ like I am.

												Realy good coop game!Kind of Diablo-like without loot or exp. You collect runes by completing level, their challenge and the time limit on them. Mor runes = more available skills; easy as that.Not to easy, you got to be fast, there are nice bosses and mini-bosses and there are puzzles to solve.Even alone i would say this is viable.The big problem at hand is the poor netcodeing. You need to readjust router-ports, anti-vir and firewalls and it will still not tell you your NAT is ok. Aside from beeing unable to connect to ppl this will also cause heavy lags in mp (which are a bad thing if you do time trails or challenges ...), but well not with everybody ...Seeing that the connecting probs cause the mp to be friend-only-groups or half-way-dead i would say: Do not buy above 10€.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												It is hard to sum up what exactly this game got wrong, when a lot of it is so close to being right. I enjoyed playing the beginning levels with my friends, but we quickly found out that in a nutshell....this game is still an unfinished and unpolished product, despite being out for a good while now.It doesn't take long to get to a level with what I consider game-breaking mechanics that just doesn't make it worthwhile to even try anymore. The frustrating thing is that it would have been really easy to implement something to fix these - like a dodge mechanic for example - and yet that was never done. It's like they released a good idea for a game that they never bothered playing or testing themselves, and then just left it alone. Therefore I recommend saving your money for a good coop game that a developer actually polishes and tests to make sure it is balanced and fun all the way through.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Hands down one of the most entertaining and fun indie games I've played in a long time, fun in both single player and multiplayer mode.Kudos to the devs for developing such an interesting gameplay and for the level design. Each stage was challenging in its own unique way and the end bosses were difficult enough while not being simple "power creeps". The strategic aspect of this game is what makes it great and extremly fun to play.These guys definitely have a thing or two to teach for what concerns design and gameplay.If there was an expansion pack with more levels available I'd definitely buy it.11/10 would recommend.Edit: Do not mind all those negative reviews that say that the game is too hard or badly designed and that one gets overwhelmed too easily and such. They're just people who didn't take the time to learn the mechanics of the game and are used to tunnelvision monorail playstyles where everything is already pre-cooked and easy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												This is quite possibly, in my opinion of course, the greatest game I have ever played.  It has four very different and very fun classes, which you can switch between any time you want.  You can play it solo, or you can go co-op and play with both friends and strangers.  The game used to be almost entirely unplayable, as there were so many connection issues that it was impossible to play with others and this is an extremely co-op oriented game.  However, since then the devs have pretty much completely rewritten all network related code and spent a huge amount of time bug hunting, which shows a tremendous amount of dedication as this is the first and only game created by a new and very small company.  However, it did take a while for them to update it considering how much they had to fix, so many people who initially played the game have since forgotten it and not updated the reviews they left half a year ago, so the game's Steam rating is fairly inaccurate.If you like challenging, co-op based games that involve both problem solving and skill on an intense yet doable difficulty curve, I highly recommend this game.  However while you can play it casually, you will not get much out of it nor will you get very far, so if that's what you're looking for do NOT buy it.

												This is a fun co-op game where you can either play solo or with up to 3 other players (so 4 in total). Each player wields a different weapon. The further you progress, the more gems you get the more (passive and active) abilities you unlock and the more abilies you can equip (3 active and 3 passive abilties in total).This is basicly a puzzle game where you have to use your spirit mentor Balfus to activate or destroy items. Each person can summon this spirit to his/her current position, but while Balfus is moving to that location, another player might summon him and thus you can get very annoyed with each other :D Get ready to work as a team...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												I had fun playing this game. Having first played through the first few levels with some friends until we stopped for a while, I had decided to pick it back up on my own after a few years. Yeesh... this game is tough on your own!I found that many challenges took a lot of observation and some trial-and-error until I found the right setup of skills and passives to complete them. I never felt cheated or that it was impossible to do on my own, there was always a combination (along with some patience) that worked.You are given the choice to play as one of four gladiators, each with their own weapon type: archer, shield, hammer (AoE style), and dual blades (fast single-targeting). I played as the shield for most of the challenges, as he has the ability to heal himself while moving faster, reflect enemy attacks for a duration, make himself immune to damage (and immobile) for a while, and dash through enemies. Almost every level had me rearranging my abilities to complete them, and that's what kept me going; I never felt that I was doing the same thing every level.I'd highly recommend giving this game a shot. If you have some buddies to play it with, you'll have a blast. If you don't, this game is still a lot of fun on your own and is a good challenge.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Great co-op game!  I played this LOCALLY with a gamepad and a keyboard.  Great controls on either end.  I found myself strategizing with my teammate(s) and generally having fun. Most levels after the first world (there are 4, I think) have an amazing level of difficulty.  Each level has three gems - beat the level, a "challenge" and a time trial. I generally skipped the time trial as that required you to really strategize in between waves and try over and over again to beat the level within the time limit.  Seemed like a waste of my gaming time to me, so I left it alone. however! Some of the challenges were actually really cool and most definitely add replayability.  For instance, a level would be about moving blocks around and solving a puzzle, killing some dudes, and then finding the end banner.  Easy enough, allows you to use your brain, and you get to fight quite a bit.  The challenge? Don't get hit by suicide monsters.  Adds some good challenge, but it isn't terribly difficult.  Strategy for those levels takes 1 minute or less, and a little bit of talking which is perfect.  Time trials are a different story - lots of strategy, retrying levels, and I would almost say are next to impossible with less than 3 players.In the end, I recommend this very highly to anyone that has even one other person they like to play games with. Netcode is great, no noticable lag, and steam has some great voice chat.Play!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I have a very love hate relationship with this game. I unfortunately have only had the chance to play through the single player campaign, so I am not sure how much differs between it and multiplayer. In other words, what I say about it may not apply to the entire game, just the part I have played. Now this game is obviously geared towards multiplayer, which isn't bad but for those of us who prefer single player or can only do single player, it seems a bit unfair. Even in some of the dialogue it assumes there are multiple gladiators, rarely using singular terms when refering to them. But while it is probably more difficult to do this alone, it isn't impossible. Infuriating at times, yes, but possible. For those who have not played the game i'll try to sum up the gameplay real fast.There are four 'classes' you can chooe from, and unlike what you may be used to, you do not select it at the beginning, at least not permanently. You can switch between them before each trial. Of the four I have only used 3, but i've glanced over them all. There is the DPS dagger like gloves, with quick attacks. That one I never really used. There is the heavy hitter hammer which I ended up using a lot simply because of that. The shield I only used once for a challenge but he seems to be a tank like character, meant to avoid a lot of damage. Then there is the bow, the ranged attacker which I used almost as much as the hammer. Each trial may require you to use a different set of weapons, you can't just stick with one. And I mean that, I don't mean it'll just be more difficult, some areas I cannot see you doing without a certain character.An interesting mechanic the game brings into play is your spirit mentor, Balfus, a floating orb of light that acts as your guide and support. You can summon him to different locations, which you'll to do a lot as to activate altars you have to make him pass through them. These altars can do any number of things, some are required to be activated to continue the level, some give Balfus a healing aura, while another will actually push enemies away and much more. I really liked this mechanic as at times it required you to do some thinking, which is a nice break from the usual hack and slash. I just wish there were more puzzles that required extra thought beyond the second area. Balfus will also give you advice and tell you about new additions to the trials as they appear. However. One of my biggest gripes is that there are times where his advice and warnings come after the fact. For example, there is a part in the second boss in the very beginning where something is happening to Balfus but he says nothing. And if you stay close to him, you end up caught in a shockwave that damages you. No warning, nothing. Not until LATER does he warn you of the dark pulsing. And then there are times where he doesn't say anything at all and you have to figure things out on your own, like in the third boss with the eggs.You do not level up like you would in a normal game, instead you unlock new skills and skill slots by completing challenges and gathering crystals from them. There are three crystals in each trial, one for beating the trial, another for completing that trial's challenge, and the last one is for the time trials. I'm not sure if there are different challenges in multiplayer, nor do I know how the time trials scale with more characters, but at least in singleplayer they do not waste time in making them difficult to complete, and expect to experiment with different characters to be able to complete them. And some of these challenges are quite infuriating. And don't expect to be able to get by with just completing the levels because the final trial has a requirement of, at least in singleplayer, 40 crystals. These can be difficult to get and require a lot of patience(or sheer stubborness).Now there are some things I had a problem with regarding the classes. Each one has the same amount of health, armor and speed. The dagger and archer should be much faster then the shield or hammer in movement speed, it only makes sense and you are punished for using the archer because many enemies are much faster then you, even if you are running full speed(which requires you to move your mouse in the direction your gladiator is facing btw). What makes this more annoying is that while the weakest enemies don't do a ton of damage, each hit slows you down even further. So good luck on those time trials where you have to try and avoid enemies, you'll be doing them a lot. I also have yet to see any other character besides archer being able to safetly despose of those exploding enemies without the use of a skill, which while those skills help they don't do much in situations where there are lot of them and you can't just run away till the cooldown is finished because, that's right, they're faster and will catch up with you. This is where I started to feel like the scaling for single player wasn't quite right.What caused me the most grief, however, were the challenges. By the end of it all I was ready to slam my laptop against the wall. These trials require absolute perfection at times, sometimes being borderline impossible. And since it requires you to get an extra 15 crystals to get to the final boss you have no choice but doing some of the most difficult ones. I'd suggest not doing what I did by finishing this game in one seven hour sitting, and instead do these challenges in spurts, for the sake of your sanity.Speaking of the final boss, and i'm not going to spoil anything, I have to say it was my favorite part of the whole game. The game's music is great, but the music for the final boss really got me into the mood, it made me feel like I was in the middle of a legendary struggle, so much that even after all the frustration that had been built up prior to it, I didn't rage once at a death no matter how close I came to defeating him that run. Unfortunately it is where I encountered the only bug I found in the entire game, and made the last half of the fight childs play(he got stuck running in place in the middle of the room). However I still left that boss fight feeling accomplished, which is what really matters in the end.Now my favorite aspect of the game was not the gameplay, but rather the voice acting and story. Yes, the story isn't the main focus of the game, just a given reason to explain why you are doing all this, but I really enjoyed the bits of it you got after every trial. And the voice acting was just wonderful. Balfus was masterfuly done in my opinion, which is good considering he's with you the entirety of the game. However, while I do enjoy the story, it never felt complete. Slight spoilers in this next bit, i'll mark it for those who want to avoid it.Balfus makes mention of these being the 'new guardians' and this master being the 'new master'. But never makes mention to what happened to the previous ones, or how these new ones rose to power. It's left unanswered which leaves you wondering why they even bothered mentioning it in the first place. Unless there is something extra I am missing.For all my gripes and frustration with this game, it is actually quite good and i'd recommend it to play with friends, but only do challenge if you have extreme patience or like that kind of challenge. It's a challenge experience but one that draws you in and makes you want to complete it and it never feels old, you are always coming across something new and fresh in each trial. So if you are a very casual gamer, i'd stay away, but if you are one who likes being challenged, go for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												I had fun playing this game. Having first played through the first few levels with some friends until we stopped for a while, I had decided to pick it back up on my own after a few years. Yeesh... this game is tough on your own!I found that many challenges took a lot of observation and some trial-and-error until I found the right setup of skills and passives to complete them. I never felt cheated or that it was impossible to do on my own, there was always a combination (along with some patience) that worked.You are given the choice to play as one of four gladiators, each with their own weapon type: archer, shield, hammer (AoE style), and dual blades (fast single-targeting). I played as the shield for most of the challenges, as he has the ability to heal himself while moving faster, reflect enemy attacks for a duration, make himself immune to damage (and immobile) for a while, and dash through enemies. Almost every level had me rearranging my abilities to complete them, and that's what kept me going; I never felt that I was doing the same thing every level.I'd highly recommend giving this game a shot. If you have some buddies to play it with, you'll have a blast. If you don't, this game is still a lot of fun on your own and is a good challenge.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Buy? Maybe.When I first heard of FORCED before it came out, I was definitely looking forward to playing it: At the time, the latest Gauntlet game wasn't announced and I loved the Gauntlet games from the N64 and Dreamcast systems that FORCED was inspired from and I've plunked hours into them just on single player.You don't play FORCED in singleplayer. Or rather you can, and it is very functional from the little bit that I have played, but it's is rather difficult in singleplayer and while it isn't unfair (just almost so) and I would compare it to "old school Nintendo hard" which is a good thing, but fustrating when trying to clear your backlog and just get through the next level. The worst part of this difficulty is that you level up by completeing challenges for each level: Completion challenge for completing the level, a special "objective" challenge for each level, and a time attack challenge. Many of these will not be completed by players on their first run of a level, such as avoiding certain enemies or attacks, or completing an optional level challenge. Completing the challenges give you crystals which tie in DIRECTLY to your ability to unlock new active and passive skills. Some of these challenges are probably easier with "less players in your way", but others feel like you need them. This creates a great reward for completng challenges, but is likely the reason why many players were scared off from FORCED. After all, I never bought this game due to hearing reviews about the difficulty and it wasn't until I was gifted this that I got to play this. Unfortunately, I never got a chance to play the game with the gifter or anybody else. Only a few of my friends have this game, and only a couple of them have played less than 2 hours of the game. There was only one online game when I checked, which denied my access to join. You will have to schedule a game with friends to play this co-op,.In conclusion, I really like the idea of combining almost Zelda-esque puzzles and Gauntlet gameplay. It works rather well here, though it can be quite annoying to manage a spirit to solve puzzles while in the heat of battle or harsh environmental conditions and level traps. The combat feels like what a modern interpretation of the Gauntlet games should feel like, however, the overall difficulty is probably what kept this game from being a big hit like Torchlight II or Castle Crashers - Not a ton of people know of this game and those that do aren't playing it. FORCED is missing the pick up and play casual feel of the Gauntlet games it is inspired by and because of this FORCED has slipped under the radar of most players and has stayed there.FORCED a good game, even perhaps a great game, but it is a hard recommendation for a game built around co-op with a dead player base. You should only buy this if you can get some other core gamers to play this with to completion - it is unlikely you will beat this with casual friends and family.

												Well, its always doubting to buy a game with new concepts. Its still a good amount on money you have to spend on it. We did the purchase with 4 friends. And i have to say we all like the game. It was a good purchase. (i got it gifted, but still ;) )Now,I think its a good concept. A top faced hack and slasher puzzle game where you have to face diffrent trials. On each trail you can earn 3 crystals. One on completing, one on time, and one on a specific trial based challenge. The completion is not that hard. The time and challenge are sometimes a diffrent story ;) With the crystals you can upgrade your character to make other trials easyier. The game runs smoothly and has a very nice graphic lay out if you can put it on the highest settings. ( its not that hard for your computer) For the difficulty, like some people say its to hard. Well, in my opinion its not. Its just a good challenge. I like the dificulty.Its a great game, and it becomes better if you can play it with 2-3-4 players together and have some yelling over team speak :p A challenge for a gamer who wants to challenge his own game skills !

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												This is quite possibly, in my opinion of course, the greatest game I have ever played.  It has four very different and very fun classes, which you can switch between any time you want.  You can play it solo, or you can go co-op and play with both friends and strangers.  The game used to be almost entirely unplayable, as there were so many connection issues that it was impossible to play with others and this is an extremely co-op oriented game.  However, since then the devs have pretty much completely rewritten all network related code and spent a huge amount of time bug hunting, which shows a tremendous amount of dedication as this is the first and only game created by a new and very small company.  However, it did take a while for them to update it considering how much they had to fix, so many people who initially played the game have since forgotten it and not updated the reviews they left half a year ago, so the game's Steam rating is fairly inaccurate.If you like challenging, co-op based games that involve both problem solving and skill on an intense yet doable difficulty curve, I highly recommend this game.  However while you can play it casually, you will not get much out of it nor will you get very far, so if that's what you're looking for do NOT buy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Newly released on steam is a new indy action rpg game called Forced. It’s available for $14.99 and caught my eye. If you have not already seen it, check out the story of BetaDwarf. The makers of the game living together on a shoe string budget for the last few years (even eating together to save money) in order to fulfill their dreams is probably reason enough to plop down $15 on the game but luckily there’s more than just that to give it a try.Forced puts you in the role of a gladiator, who’s tribe is more or less only in existence to breed warriors who take on deadly challenges for the enjoyment of others. Now that you’re old enough to fight or whatnot you are sent into the halls of trials to await your destiny. Which is probably going to involve you being killed almost immediately. After a basic tutorial the game opens up into a series of challenges you can run each in growing complexity and difficulty. You have four classes of gear to chose from and the more challenges you complete the more skill points you unlock to become more and more powerful.As you get yourself into the game you will notice quite quickly, this game is HARD. But it’s not hard in a cheap OMG WHAT WAS THAT ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T!?!? sort of way. No it’s hard because it is unforgivably difficult. The game doesn’t hold any punches and it hits you hard from early on and never lets up. You know how there are those crazy people who are addicted to spicy foods and must find the absolutely most spicy thing around? (Usually because they are addicted to endorphins) Well this game is like eating the spiciest of peppers with no milk to wash it down with. To a lot of us we’ll spit it out, frustrated by the game’s infuriating difficulty but there are some who will absolutely love it.Here’s the thing, with easy games you get less triumph from your successes. Sure they might give you a constant supply of ‘oh nice’ over and over again but eventually it doesn’t really feel like much accomplishment. Forced on the other hand is so brutally difficult that after failure after failure after failure when you finally succeed oh it feels so succulent, so sweet, so amazing. The game manages to walk a very fine line of being so difficult that success is amazingly rare while also giving you just enough hope that you might possibly figure out how to succeed, just maybe.One of the things I really like about Forced is the way they handle character progression. Yes there are four distinct classes to play but you can switch freely between them before each challenge. Also you can pick your skills freely each challenge as well. This makes choosing the class and what skills vitally important before each challenge as some are better at certain things than others. It’s also important to get familiar with each class as opposed to only playing one as you might be unnecessarily handicapping yourself in a challenge. The classes are fairly unique with a defender, a ranger, a brute heavy melee, and a faster more finesse melee. Each have their own weakness and strengths and if you are struggling with a challenge it might be time to switch up the classes or skill load out.Each challenge has three crystals (or skill points, really) available to be earned. The first is earned by simply defeating the challenge. A second is offered for doing some sort of optional skill mission and a third for completing the challenge in a certain amount of time. The more crystals you unlock the stronger your character gets, which should, in theory, make it easier to do more challenges. I like the skill system with active and passive abilities to chose from and having more options unlocked as you acquire more crystals. You are also able to have more skills active the as you go along, greatly increasing your character’s potency. Combat is also fairly smooth. Your character moves independently of the direction you’re aiming and combat uses a ‘mark’ gimmick. Each time you hit an enemy with your normal attack increases the effect of your special attack up to five times. So it’s best to prep enemies with normal attacks then hit them with specials, rinse and repeat. It’s fairly straight forward and works pretty well while adding extra tension as you try to get five marks on a big baddy before you unleash your awesome special attack.Now Forced is not without its flaws. I imagine the game would be really fun to play online (or really frustrating depending on who you play with.) But alas after trying a few times I was unable to connect to a game. I suspect the issue is probably with my firewall or something but just frustrating when internet connectivity gets in the way (seriously, why can’t online games just *work* these days?) Also if you change the controls the menus and options don’t update to match your custom control scheme which can get a wee bit annoying when trying to navigate menus or load out your skills. Also I’m not sure if it’s a big complaint or not but there is no loot in the game as the only rewards you get for completing quests are skill unlocking crystals. This can add even more frustration when you’re trying to unlock extra crystals and are unable to beat a challenge fast enough. I guess it is just how I am but darn-it I like loot!The game certainly looks a lot better than most indy games I’ve played recently. And everything is fairly smoothed and well polished. The challenges offer a fairly good variety and do a great job of mixing combat and puzzles. I can tell that the developers have put their heart and soul into the product and even though it is probably too difficult for me I can still appreciate their work. And it just feels so good to finally get a victory on a challenge that kicked my♥♥♥♥♥five times in a row! If you love a good challenge, get this game. If you can’t handle getting frustrated at a game, maybe you should pass.Final Score:Graphics: 8/10Game Play: 8/10Music / Ambiance: 8/10Story: 7/10Value: 9/10Overall: 8/10Read more indy game reviews on my blog!http://markofithian.com

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												Forced is an interesting take on a co-op hack and slash. The foundation of the game  is sort of like Gauntlet, a  top down game where you pick a class and then mow down mobs and move through the battle areana. But, fun as that is, that's not the point of the game. Each level has a puzzle or objective. Some of these are pretty tricky, and not only do you have to figure them out, but then you have to somehow execute that plan while still dealing with the monsters and fire being thrown at you. So, imagine solving group puzzles and tossing balls back and forth, all while trying to survive wave after wave of fairly difficult enemies.In any case this game makes for great co-op play, and while difficulty curve starts out gentle, it gets really high. This isn't a game you can just breeze through without a thought, it's a fun little co-op challenge.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Buy? Maybe.When I first heard of FORCED before it came out, I was definitely looking forward to playing it: At the time, the latest Gauntlet game wasn't announced and I loved the Gauntlet games from the N64 and Dreamcast systems that FORCED was inspired from and I've plunked hours into them just on single player.You don't play FORCED in singleplayer. Or rather you can, and it is very functional from the little bit that I have played, but it's is rather difficult in singleplayer and while it isn't unfair (just almost so) and I would compare it to "old school Nintendo hard" which is a good thing, but fustrating when trying to clear your backlog and just get through the next level. The worst part of this difficulty is that you level up by completeing challenges for each level: Completion challenge for completing the level, a special "objective" challenge for each level, and a time attack challenge. Many of these will not be completed by players on their first run of a level, such as avoiding certain enemies or attacks, or completing an optional level challenge. Completing the challenges give you crystals which tie in DIRECTLY to your ability to unlock new active and passive skills. Some of these challenges are probably easier with "less players in your way", but others feel like you need them. This creates a great reward for completng challenges, but is likely the reason why many players were scared off from FORCED. After all, I never bought this game due to hearing reviews about the difficulty and it wasn't until I was gifted this that I got to play this. Unfortunately, I never got a chance to play the game with the gifter or anybody else. Only a few of my friends have this game, and only a couple of them have played less than 2 hours of the game. There was only one online game when I checked, which denied my access to join. You will have to schedule a game with friends to play this co-op,.In conclusion, I really like the idea of combining almost Zelda-esque puzzles and Gauntlet gameplay. It works rather well here, though it can be quite annoying to manage a spirit to solve puzzles while in the heat of battle or harsh environmental conditions and level traps. The combat feels like what a modern interpretation of the Gauntlet games should feel like, however, the overall difficulty is probably what kept this game from being a big hit like Torchlight II or Castle Crashers - Not a ton of people know of this game and those that do aren't playing it. FORCED is missing the pick up and play casual feel of the Gauntlet games it is inspired by and because of this FORCED has slipped under the radar of most players and has stayed there.FORCED a good game, even perhaps a great game, but it is a hard recommendation for a game built around co-op with a dead player base. You should only buy this if you can get some other core gamers to play this with to completion - it is unlikely you will beat this with casual friends and family.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I'm more of a solo player bun I have to say, you need to play Forced in Co-op. There are games that have Co-op tacked on by just increasing monster HP or numbers, and then there are games that change the mechanics completely when you play Co-op. I'm happy to say Forced is designed exceptionally well as a Co-op game. It's one of the most fun games I've ever played with a friend. On the first levels you might think "Oh, only 3 active abilities and 3 passives, that's gonna get old pretty quick." Well I can hapilly tell you that the number of buttons you can push will be the least of your worries. Almost every level has new mechanics. If it doesn't it will combine previously known mechanics in unexpected ways to kill you. In co-op the skill ceiling for each level is very high since coordination plays such a crucial role. The abilities and passives you get as each class also perform various roles and synergize well with both your other abilities and with those of your partners, making the execution of a combo that wipes out the room very satisfying and also quite necessary later on in the game.So if you enjoy amazing fight design, good class synergy and a coordinating with a friend I say pick this up. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Great co-op game!  I played this LOCALLY with a gamepad and a keyboard.  Great controls on either end.  I found myself strategizing with my teammate(s) and generally having fun. Most levels after the first world (there are 4, I think) have an amazing level of difficulty.  Each level has three gems - beat the level, a "challenge" and a time trial. I generally skipped the time trial as that required you to really strategize in between waves and try over and over again to beat the level within the time limit.  Seemed like a waste of my gaming time to me, so I left it alone. however! Some of the challenges were actually really cool and most definitely add replayability.  For instance, a level would be about moving blocks around and solving a puzzle, killing some dudes, and then finding the end banner.  Easy enough, allows you to use your brain, and you get to fight quite a bit.  The challenge? Don't get hit by suicide monsters.  Adds some good challenge, but it isn't terribly difficult.  Strategy for those levels takes 1 minute or less, and a little bit of talking which is perfect.  Time trials are a different story - lots of strategy, retrying levels, and I would almost say are next to impossible with less than 3 players.In the end, I recommend this very highly to anyone that has even one other person they like to play games with. Netcode is great, no noticable lag, and steam has some great voice chat.Play!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I have a very love hate relationship with this game. I unfortunately have only had the chance to play through the single player campaign, so I am not sure how much differs between it and multiplayer. In other words, what I say about it may not apply to the entire game, just the part I have played. Now this game is obviously geared towards multiplayer, which isn't bad but for those of us who prefer single player or can only do single player, it seems a bit unfair. Even in some of the dialogue it assumes there are multiple gladiators, rarely using singular terms when refering to them. But while it is probably more difficult to do this alone, it isn't impossible. Infuriating at times, yes, but possible. For those who have not played the game i'll try to sum up the gameplay real fast.There are four 'classes' you can chooe from, and unlike what you may be used to, you do not select it at the beginning, at least not permanently. You can switch between them before each trial. Of the four I have only used 3, but i've glanced over them all. There is the DPS dagger like gloves, with quick attacks. That one I never really used. There is the heavy hitter hammer which I ended up using a lot simply because of that. The shield I only used once for a challenge but he seems to be a tank like character, meant to avoid a lot of damage. Then there is the bow, the ranged attacker which I used almost as much as the hammer. Each trial may require you to use a different set of weapons, you can't just stick with one. And I mean that, I don't mean it'll just be more difficult, some areas I cannot see you doing without a certain character.An interesting mechanic the game brings into play is your spirit mentor, Balfus, a floating orb of light that acts as your guide and support. You can summon him to different locations, which you'll to do a lot as to activate altars you have to make him pass through them. These altars can do any number of things, some are required to be activated to continue the level, some give Balfus a healing aura, while another will actually push enemies away and much more. I really liked this mechanic as at times it required you to do some thinking, which is a nice break from the usual hack and slash. I just wish there were more puzzles that required extra thought beyond the second area. Balfus will also give you advice and tell you about new additions to the trials as they appear. However. One of my biggest gripes is that there are times where his advice and warnings come after the fact. For example, there is a part in the second boss in the very beginning where something is happening to Balfus but he says nothing. And if you stay close to him, you end up caught in a shockwave that damages you. No warning, nothing. Not until LATER does he warn you of the dark pulsing. And then there are times where he doesn't say anything at all and you have to figure things out on your own, like in the third boss with the eggs.You do not level up like you would in a normal game, instead you unlock new skills and skill slots by completing challenges and gathering crystals from them. There are three crystals in each trial, one for beating the trial, another for completing that trial's challenge, and the last one is for the time trials. I'm not sure if there are different challenges in multiplayer, nor do I know how the time trials scale with more characters, but at least in singleplayer they do not waste time in making them difficult to complete, and expect to experiment with different characters to be able to complete them. And some of these challenges are quite infuriating. And don't expect to be able to get by with just completing the levels because the final trial has a requirement of, at least in singleplayer, 40 crystals. These can be difficult to get and require a lot of patience(or sheer stubborness).Now there are some things I had a problem with regarding the classes. Each one has the same amount of health, armor and speed. The dagger and archer should be much faster then the shield or hammer in movement speed, it only makes sense and you are punished for using the archer because many enemies are much faster then you, even if you are running full speed(which requires you to move your mouse in the direction your gladiator is facing btw). What makes this more annoying is that while the weakest enemies don't do a ton of damage, each hit slows you down even further. So good luck on those time trials where you have to try and avoid enemies, you'll be doing them a lot. I also have yet to see any other character besides archer being able to safetly despose of those exploding enemies without the use of a skill, which while those skills help they don't do much in situations where there are lot of them and you can't just run away till the cooldown is finished because, that's right, they're faster and will catch up with you. This is where I started to feel like the scaling for single player wasn't quite right.What caused me the most grief, however, were the challenges. By the end of it all I was ready to slam my laptop against the wall. These trials require absolute perfection at times, sometimes being borderline impossible. And since it requires you to get an extra 15 crystals to get to the final boss you have no choice but doing some of the most difficult ones. I'd suggest not doing what I did by finishing this game in one seven hour sitting, and instead do these challenges in spurts, for the sake of your sanity.Speaking of the final boss, and i'm not going to spoil anything, I have to say it was my favorite part of the whole game. The game's music is great, but the music for the final boss really got me into the mood, it made me feel like I was in the middle of a legendary struggle, so much that even after all the frustration that had been built up prior to it, I didn't rage once at a death no matter how close I came to defeating him that run. Unfortunately it is where I encountered the only bug I found in the entire game, and made the last half of the fight childs play(he got stuck running in place in the middle of the room). However I still left that boss fight feeling accomplished, which is what really matters in the end.Now my favorite aspect of the game was not the gameplay, but rather the voice acting and story. Yes, the story isn't the main focus of the game, just a given reason to explain why you are doing all this, but I really enjoyed the bits of it you got after every trial. And the voice acting was just wonderful. Balfus was masterfuly done in my opinion, which is good considering he's with you the entirety of the game. However, while I do enjoy the story, it never felt complete. Slight spoilers in this next bit, i'll mark it for those who want to avoid it.Balfus makes mention of these being the 'new guardians' and this master being the 'new master'. But never makes mention to what happened to the previous ones, or how these new ones rose to power. It's left unanswered which leaves you wondering why they even bothered mentioning it in the first place. Unless there is something extra I am missing.For all my gripes and frustration with this game, it is actually quite good and i'd recommend it to play with friends, but only do challenge if you have extreme patience or like that kind of challenge. It's a challenge experience but one that draws you in and makes you want to complete it and it never feels old, you are always coming across something new and fresh in each trial. So if you are a very casual gamer, i'd stay away, but if you are one who likes being challenged, go for it.

												I totally recommend this game, even though (and perhaps just exactly why) some levels are CRAZY hard (even annoying a times). The central element of the game lies in swapping between the different characters and maybe even changing the number of people playing (I finished all trials with in 2player, except for the second-to-last one, which I did alone).Graphics and music are standard in quality, nothing extraordinary, the story even a little sub-standard, but that's not quite the point with games like this one.The only annoying technical aspect is the network performance, which, even though it was improved with just about every update, still isn't perfect now.All in all, I award this game 4.5 stars, the half one being lost because of the lagging issues, the weak story and because some trials are just too hard.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is a pretty cool game, with some annoying issues. You (and a few others if you play online) must complete a series of challenges to advance. You're afforded the choice of four different weapons - they all play quite differently and come with their own set of abilities and buffs. And each challenge gives you up to three crystals, and when you get a number of crystals, you get new abilities. It's a pretty unique take on this type of game, as you can't really 'grind' to level up, at most you can get a couple new buffs to help yourself out, if you master previous challenges. Because of this, it comes down more to strategy and skill, and can become quite fun in some segments. Sometimes, however, things can be a pain in the butt. Certain challenges or bosses seem to combine the most annoying parts of the game all in one, in seemingly unfair ways. And though the game says that it's balanced for either 1-4 players, more players simply make it easier in so many ways. That said, I really enjoyed the game, when it wasn't being irritating, and would recommend it to others who are looking for a challenging title to play along with friends.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I'm more of a solo player bun I have to say, you need to play Forced in Co-op. There are games that have Co-op tacked on by just increasing monster HP or numbers, and then there are games that change the mechanics completely when you play Co-op. I'm happy to say Forced is designed exceptionally well as a Co-op game. It's one of the most fun games I've ever played with a friend. On the first levels you might think "Oh, only 3 active abilities and 3 passives, that's gonna get old pretty quick." Well I can hapilly tell you that the number of buttons you can push will be the least of your worries. Almost every level has new mechanics. If it doesn't it will combine previously known mechanics in unexpected ways to kill you. In co-op the skill ceiling for each level is very high since coordination plays such a crucial role. The abilities and passives you get as each class also perform various roles and synergize well with both your other abilities and with those of your partners, making the execution of a combo that wipes out the room very satisfying and also quite necessary later on in the game.So if you enjoy amazing fight design, good class synergy and a coordinating with a friend I say pick this up. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Great co-op game!  I played this LOCALLY with a gamepad and a keyboard.  Great controls on either end.  I found myself strategizing with my teammate(s) and generally having fun. Most levels after the first world (there are 4, I think) have an amazing level of difficulty.  Each level has three gems - beat the level, a "challenge" and a time trial. I generally skipped the time trial as that required you to really strategize in between waves and try over and over again to beat the level within the time limit.  Seemed like a waste of my gaming time to me, so I left it alone. however! Some of the challenges were actually really cool and most definitely add replayability.  For instance, a level would be about moving blocks around and solving a puzzle, killing some dudes, and then finding the end banner.  Easy enough, allows you to use your brain, and you get to fight quite a bit.  The challenge? Don't get hit by suicide monsters.  Adds some good challenge, but it isn't terribly difficult.  Strategy for those levels takes 1 minute or less, and a little bit of talking which is perfect.  Time trials are a different story - lots of strategy, retrying levels, and I would almost say are next to impossible with less than 3 players.In the end, I recommend this very highly to anyone that has even one other person they like to play games with. Netcode is great, no noticable lag, and steam has some great voice chat.Play!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is a pretty cool game, with some annoying issues. You (and a few others if you play online) must complete a series of challenges to advance. You're afforded the choice of four different weapons - they all play quite differently and come with their own set of abilities and buffs. And each challenge gives you up to three crystals, and when you get a number of crystals, you get new abilities. It's a pretty unique take on this type of game, as you can't really 'grind' to level up, at most you can get a couple new buffs to help yourself out, if you master previous challenges. Because of this, it comes down more to strategy and skill, and can become quite fun in some segments. Sometimes, however, things can be a pain in the butt. Certain challenges or bosses seem to combine the most annoying parts of the game all in one, in seemingly unfair ways. And though the game says that it's balanced for either 1-4 players, more players simply make it easier in so many ways. That said, I really enjoyed the game, when it wasn't being irritating, and would recommend it to others who are looking for a challenging title to play along with friends.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Pretty fun!Basic gameplay is simple but fun, the combat system is not really that deep but has nice gimmicks. The presentation is really polished, there's non-grindy customization and coop is entertaining (don't buy for the singleplayer experience). Survival mode is a bit frustrating because I am bad at not ♥♥♥♥ing up and having to replay the slow starting bits.Overall I'd have preferred more engaging and varied combat challenges and less gimmicky puzzles, though the way the puzzly bits integrate with the fighty bits is nice. The good parts are kind of like WoW boss fights with frantic gimmick management while half the party gets eaten by ghouls. Hoping they'll churn out more content that's less linear and "do the thing, then do the thing again with a gimmick, then do the thing again within 3 minutes"-focused.We had some weird technical issues with the game silencing mumble(???) on Windows. Steam voice or skype or whatever worked fine. The game runs flawlessly on Linux, though I haven't tried it with a gamepad.
