number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I have a very love hate relationship with this game. I unfortunately have only had the chance to play through the single player campaign, so I am not sure how much differs between it and multiplayer. In other words, what I say about it may not apply to the entire game, just the part I have played. Now this game is obviously geared towards multiplayer, which isn't bad but for those of us who prefer single player or can only do single player, it seems a bit unfair. Even in some of the dialogue it assumes there are multiple gladiators, rarely using singular terms when refering to them. But while it is probably more difficult to do this alone, it isn't impossible. Infuriating at times, yes, but possible. For those who have not played the game i'll try to sum up the gameplay real fast.There are four 'classes' you can chooe from, and unlike what you may be used to, you do not select it at the beginning, at least not permanently. You can switch between them before each trial. Of the four I have only used 3, but i've glanced over them all. There is the DPS dagger like gloves, with quick attacks. That one I never really used. There is the heavy hitter hammer which I ended up using a lot simply because of that. The shield I only used once for a challenge but he seems to be a tank like character, meant to avoid a lot of damage. Then there is the bow, the ranged attacker which I used almost as much as the hammer. Each trial may require you to use a different set of weapons, you can't just stick with one. And I mean that, I don't mean it'll just be more difficult, some areas I cannot see you doing without a certain character.An interesting mechanic the game brings into play is your spirit mentor, Balfus, a floating orb of light that acts as your guide and support. You can summon him to different locations, which you'll to do a lot as to activate altars you have to make him pass through them. These altars can do any number of things, some are required to be activated to continue the level, some give Balfus a healing aura, while another will actually push enemies away and much more. I really liked this mechanic as at times it required you to do some thinking, which is a nice break from the usual hack and slash. I just wish there were more puzzles that required extra thought beyond the second area. Balfus will also give you advice and tell you about new additions to the trials as they appear. However. One of my biggest gripes is that there are times where his advice and warnings come after the fact. For example, there is a part in the second boss in the very beginning where something is happening to Balfus but he says nothing. And if you stay close to him, you end up caught in a shockwave that damages you. No warning, nothing. Not until LATER does he warn you of the dark pulsing. And then there are times where he doesn't say anything at all and you have to figure things out on your own, like in the third boss with the eggs.You do not level up like you would in a normal game, instead you unlock new skills and skill slots by completing challenges and gathering crystals from them. There are three crystals in each trial, one for beating the trial, another for completing that trial's challenge, and the last one is for the time trials. I'm not sure if there are different challenges in multiplayer, nor do I know how the time trials scale with more characters, but at least in singleplayer they do not waste time in making them difficult to complete, and expect to experiment with different characters to be able to complete them. And some of these challenges are quite infuriating. And don't expect to be able to get by with just completing the levels because the final trial has a requirement of, at least in singleplayer, 40 crystals. These can be difficult to get and require a lot of patience(or sheer stubborness).Now there are some things I had a problem with regarding the classes. Each one has the same amount of health, armor and speed. The dagger and archer should be much faster then the shield or hammer in movement speed, it only makes sense and you are punished for using the archer because many enemies are much faster then you, even if you are running full speed(which requires you to move your mouse in the direction your gladiator is facing btw). What makes this more annoying is that while the weakest enemies don't do a ton of damage, each hit slows you down even further. So good luck on those time trials where you have to try and avoid enemies, you'll be doing them a lot. I also have yet to see any other character besides archer being able to safetly despose of those exploding enemies without the use of a skill, which while those skills help they don't do much in situations where there are lot of them and you can't just run away till the cooldown is finished because, that's right, they're faster and will catch up with you. This is where I started to feel like the scaling for single player wasn't quite right.What caused me the most grief, however, were the challenges. By the end of it all I was ready to slam my laptop against the wall. These trials require absolute perfection at times, sometimes being borderline impossible. And since it requires you to get an extra 15 crystals to get to the final boss you have no choice but doing some of the most difficult ones. I'd suggest not doing what I did by finishing this game in one seven hour sitting, and instead do these challenges in spurts, for the sake of your sanity.Speaking of the final boss, and i'm not going to spoil anything, I have to say it was my favorite part of the whole game. The game's music is great, but the music for the final boss really got me into the mood, it made me feel like I was in the middle of a legendary struggle, so much that even after all the frustration that had been built up prior to it, I didn't rage once at a death no matter how close I came to defeating him that run. Unfortunately it is where I encountered the only bug I found in the entire game, and made the last half of the fight childs play(he got stuck running in place in the middle of the room). However I still left that boss fight feeling accomplished, which is what really matters in the end.Now my favorite aspect of the game was not the gameplay, but rather the voice acting and story. Yes, the story isn't the main focus of the game, just a given reason to explain why you are doing all this, but I really enjoyed the bits of it you got after every trial. And the voice acting was just wonderful. Balfus was masterfuly done in my opinion, which is good considering he's with you the entirety of the game. However, while I do enjoy the story, it never felt complete. Slight spoilers in this next bit, i'll mark it for those who want to avoid it.Balfus makes mention of these being the 'new guardians' and this master being the 'new master'. But never makes mention to what happened to the previous ones, or how these new ones rose to power. It's left unanswered which leaves you wondering why they even bothered mentioning it in the first place. Unless there is something extra I am missing.For all my gripes and frustration with this game, it is actually quite good and i'd recommend it to play with friends, but only do challenge if you have extreme patience or like that kind of challenge. It's a challenge experience but one that draws you in and makes you want to complete it and it never feels old, you are always coming across something new and fresh in each trial. So if you are a very casual gamer, i'd stay away, but if you are one who likes being challenged, go for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Buy? Maybe.When I first heard of FORCED before it came out, I was definitely looking forward to playing it: At the time, the latest Gauntlet game wasn't announced and I loved the Gauntlet games from the N64 and Dreamcast systems that FORCED was inspired from and I've plunked hours into them just on single player.You don't play FORCED in singleplayer. Or rather you can, and it is very functional from the little bit that I have played, but it's is rather difficult in singleplayer and while it isn't unfair (just almost so) and I would compare it to "old school Nintendo hard" which is a good thing, but fustrating when trying to clear your backlog and just get through the next level. The worst part of this difficulty is that you level up by completeing challenges for each level: Completion challenge for completing the level, a special "objective" challenge for each level, and a time attack challenge. Many of these will not be completed by players on their first run of a level, such as avoiding certain enemies or attacks, or completing an optional level challenge. Completing the challenges give you crystals which tie in DIRECTLY to your ability to unlock new active and passive skills. Some of these challenges are probably easier with "less players in your way", but others feel like you need them. This creates a great reward for completng challenges, but is likely the reason why many players were scared off from FORCED. After all, I never bought this game due to hearing reviews about the difficulty and it wasn't until I was gifted this that I got to play this. Unfortunately, I never got a chance to play the game with the gifter or anybody else. Only a few of my friends have this game, and only a couple of them have played less than 2 hours of the game. There was only one online game when I checked, which denied my access to join. You will have to schedule a game with friends to play this co-op,.In conclusion, I really like the idea of combining almost Zelda-esque puzzles and Gauntlet gameplay. It works rather well here, though it can be quite annoying to manage a spirit to solve puzzles while in the heat of battle or harsh environmental conditions and level traps. The combat feels like what a modern interpretation of the Gauntlet games should feel like, however, the overall difficulty is probably what kept this game from being a big hit like Torchlight II or Castle Crashers - Not a ton of people know of this game and those that do aren't playing it. FORCED is missing the pick up and play casual feel of the Gauntlet games it is inspired by and because of this FORCED has slipped under the radar of most players and has stayed there.FORCED a good game, even perhaps a great game, but it is a hard recommendation for a game built around co-op with a dead player base. You should only buy this if you can get some other core gamers to play this with to completion - it is unlikely you will beat this with casual friends and family.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Great co-op game!  I played this LOCALLY with a gamepad and a keyboard.  Great controls on either end.  I found myself strategizing with my teammate(s) and generally having fun. Most levels after the first world (there are 4, I think) have an amazing level of difficulty.  Each level has three gems - beat the level, a "challenge" and a time trial. I generally skipped the time trial as that required you to really strategize in between waves and try over and over again to beat the level within the time limit.  Seemed like a waste of my gaming time to me, so I left it alone. however! Some of the challenges were actually really cool and most definitely add replayability.  For instance, a level would be about moving blocks around and solving a puzzle, killing some dudes, and then finding the end banner.  Easy enough, allows you to use your brain, and you get to fight quite a bit.  The challenge? Don't get hit by suicide monsters.  Adds some good challenge, but it isn't terribly difficult.  Strategy for those levels takes 1 minute or less, and a little bit of talking which is perfect.  Time trials are a different story - lots of strategy, retrying levels, and I would almost say are next to impossible with less than 3 players.In the end, I recommend this very highly to anyone that has even one other person they like to play games with. Netcode is great, no noticable lag, and steam has some great voice chat.Play!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I am impressed by this little indie game. Betadwarf knocked this one out of the park. I like challenging and difficult games. It's been a while since my friends and I have had a good co-op game to play together and we've spent the majority of the past week playing it non-stop. My OCD/completionist nature kicks into high gear for the challenge and time objectives of each mission. I cannot move on to the next trial without completing its predecessor in its entirety. Forced is highly recommended to those who like a challenge and/or complex cooperative play.More Here: http://www.pixlmuse.com/blog/review-forced

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												+Coop+Coop+4 players Coop!Oh My God, isn't it the best coop experience I've had EVER!Imagine the combination of Diablo III (mechanics), Trine 2 (puzzles), Orianna from LoL (a floating ball that you share and control) and add arenas into the mixture. You'll get the idea of FORCED. The game is easy to learn, but hard to master, The level of difficulty is well balanced, which allows you to get basic rewards from maps without greater difficulty. Should you want extra prize... You'll have to think - hard. And be good with your controller.I've spent couple of hours playing just one map with my brother and, surprisingly, we did not get bored! And the satisfaction after beating it... I hadn't felt such satisfaction while playing a video game for a long time!This is a perfect option for you, if you are (just like me) a fan of coop games, where the aspect of coperation is really vital. If you like light coop games, where you can mke it solo without a problem (like Serious Sam 3), you might get discouraged by FORCED after some time.Nonetheless, I think I will spend much more time in puzzling arcades of FORCED, without FORCING myself to do that!See you in-game! :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												This is Danish dynamite! The game is really hart to beat but lots of fun! Yet challenging it never gets unfair for there is a way to master the tasks given. And - I guess it is the most important fact - it is impossible to win the game without your team. This is not a lame phrase but virtually the truth because sometimes you have to solve ridles while timing your movement avoiding death traps and combating enemies meanwhile. There is so much going on that you have no time to pause for you'll get exhausted. Often your friends are the reason for failing or dying which in many cases is the reason for failing. I guess casual gamers will be frustrated very fast but everyone who loves a challenging coop will love this one. Give it a try, it is worth the effort.Pros+ 4x Unique characters where no one is useless+ Very broad diversification of level design+ Great ideas and good humor+ You have to solve riddles by yourself with nearly no tipps given+ Balfus (players of the game will know why)+ Challenging but not unfair (may seem so at first but it is not, watch yt vids if you do not believe it)+ Extremly well balanced+ Fast matches of only some minutes (yet you will play for longer I'm sure)Cons- No double characters in the team- Skilltrees are somehow small and many skills do not seem usefull (or my team is just dumb)- The great game controls sometime need a really perfect timing- Some more monster types would have been niceOverall:Give it a try! It is a small Danish team who created an innovative, fast playing coop! They need our money and this game is worth every penny. I even bought copies for my friends who love the game as well.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Clever and challenging action rpg but best played with 4 friends. Bought the 4 pack during the last steam sale and had a blast going through the levels. Each level is a cleverly designed arena with unique challenges. While difficult to beat the first time, each level also has a time trial and a bonus objective to complete. Beating levels, clearing under a time limit, and completing the bonus objective provides gems which unlock upgrades. Upgrades are unlocked at gem levels, so you can switch between any of the 4 playable characters at any time. Almost all the upgrades are useful and unique, so different players can have very different styles even with the same character.My only complaint about the game is that one of the later levels appears to be bugged in multiplayer and can't be completed.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												I stumbled across FORCED when it was still in "early access" state.It was in these "dark days" where games would rarely see a native Linux port, so those few who did immediately drew my attention.I did not really know of what to expect of it, but it offered a Linux version, local coop and showcased some promising screenshots, so I decided to give it a shot -  which I have yet to regret.After playing a few levels I became aware of the fact that FORCED was about to become one of the "most precious gems" of my entire game collection!It offers interesting and unique game mechanics, that are easy to learn, yet hard to master - Just like a perfect game ought to be like!Moreover there is a strong focus on coop strategies which has ever since been an important aspect of video games for me.Thanks to the BetaDwarf team for creating  such an experience!I really enjoy your game and I am looking forward to buy addons or even a successor of FORCED some day ;-)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17
You might like if: You have the endurance to master grim, gladiatorial combat; either solo or with a tightly-knit team of friends who are willing to die a lot.Forced is a very polished game, both in its concept and execution. You play as 1-4 victims, moving targets, corpses-to-be... Gladiators subject to arenas spanning a superb mix of combat, puzzles and planning. The ability to align yourself to 1 of 4 weapons is also pretty fun - particularly mixing and matching different abilities and passive bonuses. Just be aware that, in my experience, some builds (or even weapons) tend to favour certain levels more than others - so be prepared to alter your build to beat each level, as opposed to finding a single, favourite combo to play the whole game with.The levels are delightfully varied and have their own unique twist. The 3 challenges (and rewards) for each level are also a great touch: 1 for just winning, 1 for beating the time limit and 1 for overcoming a special condition. As such, there's a lot to do and a lot to master.But therein lies the catch, it's gladiatorial in more ways than one... it's bloody difficult. After the first level or 2, the ante quickly ramps up and you need to be quick on your feet, well-coordinated and honed to a fine edge. So expect to die a fair bit and understand that completing all the challenges will require a fair bit of practice (or outright stubbornness).This, too, applies to co-op; this is most definitely a cooperative game... not a party game. The game scales the number of enemies, time challenges and even puzzles with the more players you have, so the difficulty is always there. Unfortunately this means that your team will all equally need to be sharp and willing to put in the time and communication to master the levels. The game will unceremoniously prune weaker players, leaving a harder level for everyone else - which can quickly kill the fun for casual gamers. As such, single player is considerably more enjoyable than playing with an uncoordinated team, so bear this in mind if you're looking for multiplayer games to share with your gaming buddies.The final catch is that (annoyingly) the network connections between players can be a little inconsistent (though this was a few years ago). I could easily create a party of 2 players - but would always have trouble getting the 3rd on board. A bit frustrating for a game specialised for co-op.But playing solo, I've find this to be a very enjoyable and varied challenge... if a little intense at times. It's unforgiving but equally rewarding when you nail it. One to dip into when you really fancy a tough gaming wall to climb.
